Varsovian Trumpet Call  
![Map](https://maps.wikimedia.org/img/osm-intl,a,a,a,300x200.png?lang=en&domain=en.wikipedia.org&title=Warsaw&revid=1275419305&groups=_7c2d207cf66792b12560f23828690cadf325069b)  
Warsaw interactive map

**Warsaw** ,^[\[a\]](#cite_note-8)^ officially the **Capital City of Warsaw** ,^[\[8\]](#cite_note-9)^^[\[b\]](#cite_note-10)^ is the capital and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Poland "List of cities and towns in Poland") of [Poland](/wiki/Poland "Poland"). The metropolis stands on the [River Vistula](/wiki/Vistula "Vistula") in east-central Poland. Its population is officially estimated at 1.86 million residents within a [greater metropolitan area](/wiki/Warsaw_metropolitan_area "Warsaw metropolitan area") of 3.27 million residents, which makes Warsaw the [7th most-populous city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_European_Union_by_population_within_city_limits "List of cities in the European Union by population within city limits") in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union").^[\[2\]](#cite_note-GUS_-_Bank_Danych_Lokalnych-2)^ The city area measures 517 km^2^ (200 sq mi) and comprises [18 districts](/wiki/Districts_and_neighbourhoods_of_Warsaw "Districts and neighbourhoods of Warsaw"), while the metropolitan area covers 6,100 km^2^ (2,355 sq mi).^[\[9\]](#cite_note-goeuro2012-11)^ Warsaw is classified as an [alpha](/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network#Alpha_2 "Globalization and World Cities Research Network") [global city](/wiki/Global_city "Global city"),^[\[10\]](#cite_note-12)^ a major cultural, political and economic hub, and the country's seat of government. It is also the capital of the [Masovian Voivodeship](/wiki/Masovian_Voivodeship "Masovian Voivodeship").{#cite_ref-12}

Warsaw traces its origins to a small fishing town in [Masovia](/wiki/Masovia "Masovia"). The city rose to prominence in the late 16th century, when [Sigismund III](/wiki/Sigismund_III "Sigismund III") decided to move the Polish capital and his royal court from [Kraków](/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w "Kraków"). Warsaw served as the de facto capital of the [Polish--Lithuanian Commonwealth](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth "Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth") until 1795, and subsequently as the seat of [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon "Napoleon")'s [Duchy of Warsaw](/wiki/Duchy_of_Warsaw "Duchy of Warsaw"). The 19th century and its [Industrial Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution") brought a demographic boom, which made it one of the largest and most densely populated cities in Europe. Known then for its elegant architecture and boulevards, Warsaw was [bombed](/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland "Invasion of Poland") and [besieged](/wiki/Siege_of_Warsaw_(1939) "Siege of Warsaw (1939)") at the start of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") in 1939.^[\[11\]](#cite_note-coat_of_arms-13)^^[\[12\]](#cite_note-Czerkawski-14)^^[\[13\]](#cite_note-15)^ Much of the historic city was destroyed and its diverse population decimated by the [Ghetto Uprising](/wiki/Warsaw_Ghetto_Uprising "Warsaw Ghetto Uprising") in 1943, the general [Warsaw Uprising](/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising "Warsaw Uprising") in 1944, and [systematic razing](/wiki/Destruction_of_Warsaw "Destruction of Warsaw").{#cite_ref-15}

Warsaw is served by three international airports, the busiest being [Warsaw Chopin](/wiki/Warsaw_Chopin_Airport "Warsaw Chopin Airport"), as well as [Warsaw Modlin](/wiki/Warsaw_Modlin_Airport "Warsaw Modlin Airport") and [Warsaw Radom Airport](/wiki/Warsaw_Radom_Airport "Warsaw Radom Airport"). Major public transport services operating in the city include the [Warsaw Metro](/wiki/Warsaw_Metro "Warsaw Metro"), [buses](/wiki/Bus_transport_in_Warsaw "Bus transport in Warsaw"), [commuter rail service](/wiki/Szybka_Kolej_Miejska_(Warsaw) "Szybka Kolej Miejska (Warsaw)") and an extensive [tram network](/wiki/Trams_in_Warsaw "Trams in Warsaw"). The city is a significant economic centre for the region, with the [Warsaw Stock Exchange](/wiki/Warsaw_Stock_Exchange "Warsaw Stock Exchange") being the largest in [Central](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe") and [Eastern Europe](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe").^[\[14\]](#cite_note-16)^^[\[15\]](#cite_note-17)^ It is the base for [Frontex](/wiki/Frontex "Frontex"), the [European Union agency](/wiki/Agencies_of_the_European_Union "Agencies of the European Union") for external border security, and [ODIHR](/wiki/ODIHR "ODIHR"), one of the principal institutions of the [Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe](/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe "Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe"). Warsaw has one of Europe's highest [concentrations of skyscrapers](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Warsaw "List of tallest buildings in Warsaw"), and the [Varso Place](/wiki/Varso "Varso") is the tallest building in the European Union.{#cite_ref-17}

The city's primary educational and cultural institutions comprise the [University of Warsaw](/wiki/University_of_Warsaw "University of Warsaw"), the [Warsaw University of Technology](/wiki/Warsaw_University_of_Technology "Warsaw University of Technology"), the [SGH Warsaw School of Economics](/wiki/SGH_Warsaw_School_of_Economics "SGH Warsaw School of Economics"), the [Chopin University of Music](/wiki/Chopin_University_of_Music "Chopin University of Music"), the [Polish Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Polish_Academy_of_Sciences "Polish Academy of Sciences"), the [National Philharmonic Orchestra](/wiki/Warsaw_National_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Warsaw National Philharmonic Orchestra"), the [National Museum](/wiki/National_Museum,_Warsaw "National Museum, Warsaw"), and the [Warsaw Grand Theatre](/wiki/Grand_Theatre,_Warsaw "Grand Theatre, Warsaw"), the largest of its kind in the world.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-18)^ The reconstructed [Old Town](/wiki/Old_Town,_Warsaw "Old Town, Warsaw"), which represents a variety of European architectural styles, was listed as a [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") in 1980.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-19)^ Other landmarks include the [Royal Castle](/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw "Royal Castle, Warsaw"), [Sigismund's Column](/wiki/Sigismund%27s_Column "Sigismund's Column"), the [Wilanów Palace](/wiki/Wilan%C3%B3w_Palace "Wilanów Palace"), the [Palace on the Isle](/wiki/Palace_on_the_Isle "Palace on the Isle"), [St. John's Archcathedral](/wiki/St._John%27s_Archcathedral,_Warsaw "St. John's Archcathedral, Warsaw"), [Main Market Square](/wiki/Old_Town_Market_Place,_Warsaw "Old Town Market Place, Warsaw"), and numerous churches and mansions along the [Royal Route](/wiki/Royal_Route,_Warsaw "Royal Route, Warsaw"). Warsaw is a green capital, with around a quarter of the city's area occupied by parks.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-20)^^[\[19\]](#cite_note-eastern_europe_capital-21)^ In sports, the city is home to [Legia Warsaw](/wiki/Legia_Warsaw "Legia Warsaw") football club and hosts the annual [Warsaw Marathon](/wiki/Warsaw_Marathon "Warsaw Marathon").{#cite_ref-eastern_europe_capital_21-0}  

Toponymy and names {#Toponymy_and_names}
----------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Toponymy and names")\]

Warsaw's name in the [Polish language](/wiki/Polish_language "Polish language") is *Warszawa*. Other previous spellings of the name may have included: *Warszewa*, *Warszowa*, *Worszewa* or *Werszewa*.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-22)^^[\[21\]](#cite_note-23)^ The exact origin and meaning of the name is uncertain and has not been fully determined.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-24)^^[\[23\]](#cite_note-25)^ Originally, Warszawa was the name of a small fishing settlement on the banks of the [Vistula](/wiki/Vistula "Vistula") river. One hypothesis states that *Warszawa* means "belonging to Warsz", *Warsz* being a shortened form of the masculine [Old Polish](/wiki/Old_Polish "Old Polish") name Warcisław, which etymologically is linked with [Wrocław](/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw "Wrocław").^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Rymut-26)^ However the ending -awa is unusual for a large city; the names of Polish cities derived from personal names usually end in -ów/owo/ew/ewo (e.g. Piotrków, Adamów).{#cite_ref-Rymut_26-0}

[Folk etymology](/wiki/False_etymology "False etymology") attributes the city name to [Wars and Sawa](/wiki/Wars_and_Sawa "Wars and Sawa"). There are several versions of the legend with their appearance. According to one version, Sawa was a mermaid living in the Vistula with whom fisherman Wars fell in love.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-warsaw-legend-27)^^[\[26\]](#cite_note-syrenka_historia-28)^ The official city name in full is *miasto stołeczne Warszawa* ("The Capital City of Warsaw").^[\[27\]](#cite_note-prawo_lex-29)^{#cite_ref-prawo_lex_29-0}

A native or resident of Warsaw is known as a *Varsovian* -- in Polish *warszawiak*, *warszawianin* (male), *warszawianka* (female), *warszawiacy*, and *warszawianie* (plural).  
For the name of Warsaw in various languages, see [wikt:Warsaw](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Warsaw "wikt:Warsaw").  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Warsaw](/wiki/History_of_Warsaw "History of Warsaw")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Warsaw](/wiki/Timeline_of_Warsaw "Timeline of Warsaw").  

### 1300--1800 {#1300.E2.80.931800}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: 1300–1800")\]

The first fortified settlements on the site of today's Warsaw were located in [Bródno](/wiki/Br%C3%B3dno "Bródno") (9th/10th century) and [Jazdów](/wiki/Ujazd%C3%B3w_Castle "Ujazdów Castle") (12th/13th century).^[\[28\]](#cite_note-history-30)^ After Jazdów was raided by nearby clans and dukes, a new fortified settlement was established on the site of a small fishing village called "Warszowa". The Prince of [Płock](/wiki/P%C5%82ock "Płock"), Bolesław II of Masovia, established the modern-day city in about 1300 and the first historical document attesting to the existence of a [castellany](/wiki/Castellan "Castellan") dates to 1313.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-views-31)^ With the completion of [St John's Cathedral](/wiki/St._John%27s_Archcathedral,_Warsaw "St. John's Archcathedral, Warsaw") in 1390, Warsaw became one of the seats of the [Dukes of Masovia](/wiki/Duke_of_Masovia "Duke of Masovia") and was officially made capital of the [Masovian Duchy](/wiki/Duchy_of_Masovia "Duchy of Masovia") in 1413.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-history-30)^ The economy then predominantly rested on craftsmanship or trade, and the town housed approximately 4,500 people at the time.{#cite_ref-history_30-1}

During the 15th century, the population migrated and spread beyond the northern city wall into a newly formed self-governing precinct called [New Town](/wiki/Warsaw_New_Town "Warsaw New Town"). The existing older settlement became eventually known as the [Old Town](/wiki/Warsaw_Old_Town "Warsaw Old Town"). Both possessed their own town charter and independent councils. The aim of establishing a separate district was to accommodate new incomers or "undesirables" who were not permitted to settle in Old Town, particularly [Jews](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Poland "History of the Jews in Poland").^[\[30\]](#cite_note-Davies-32)^ Social and financial disparities between the classes in the two precincts led to a minor revolt in 1525.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-views-31)^ Following the sudden death of [Janusz III](/wiki/Janusz_III_of_Masovia "Janusz III of Masovia") and the extinction of the local ducal line, Masovia was incorporated into the [Kingdom of Poland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland "Kingdom of Poland") in 1526.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-history-30)^ [Bona Sforza](/wiki/Bona_Sforza "Bona Sforza"), wife of [Sigismund I of Poland](/wiki/Sigismund_I_of_Poland "Sigismund I of Poland"), was widely accused of poisoning the duke to uphold Polish rule over Warsaw.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-33)^^[\[32\]](#cite_note-34)^{#cite_ref-34}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Hogenberg_View_of_Warsaw_%28detail%29.jpg/220px-Hogenberg_View_of_Warsaw_%28detail%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hogenberg_View_of_Warsaw_(detail).jpg) A paper engraving of 16th-century Warsaw showing [St. John's Archcathedral](/wiki/St._John%27s_Archcathedral_(Warsaw) "St. John's Archcathedral (Warsaw)") to the right. The church was founded in 1390, and is one of the city's ancient and most important landmarks.

In 1529, Warsaw for the first time became the seat of a [General Sejm](/wiki/Sejm_of_the_Republic_of_Poland "Sejm of the Republic of Poland") and held that privilege permanently from 1569.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-history-30)^ The city's rising importance encouraged the construction of a new set of defenses, including the landmark [Barbican](/wiki/Warsaw_Barbican "Warsaw Barbican"). Renowned [Italian architects](/wiki/Italian_architecture "Italian architecture") were brought to Warsaw to reshape the [Royal Castle](/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw "Royal Castle, Warsaw"), the streets and the marketplace, resulting in the Old Town's early Italianate appearance. In 1573, the city gave its name to the [Warsaw Confederation](/wiki/Warsaw_Confederation "Warsaw Confederation") which formally established religious freedom in the [Polish--Lithuanian Commonwealth](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth "Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth"). Due to its central location between the capitals of the Commonwealth's two component parts, Poland and Lithuania, which were [Kraków](/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w "Kraków") and [Vilnius](/wiki/Vilnius "Vilnius") respectively, Warsaw became the capital of the Commonwealth and the [Polish Crown](/wiki/Crown_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland "Crown of the Kingdom of Poland") when [Sigismund III Vasa](/wiki/Sigismund_III_Vasa "Sigismund III Vasa") transferred his royal court in 1596.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-history-30)^ In the subsequent years the town significantly expanded to the south and westwards. Several private independent districts (*[jurydyka](/wiki/Jurydyka "Jurydyka")* ) were the property of aristocrats and the gentry, which they ruled by their own laws. Between 1655 and 1658 the city was besieged and pillaged by the Swedish, [Brandenburgian](/wiki/Margraviate_of_Brandenburg "Margraviate of Brandenburg") and [Transylvanian](/wiki/Transylvania "Transylvania") forces.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-history-30)^^[\[33\]](#cite_note-Ascheron-35)^ The conduct of the [Great Northern War](/wiki/Great_Northern_War "Great Northern War") (1700--1721) also forced Warsaw to pay heavy tributes to the invading armies.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-timeline-36)^{#cite_ref-timeline_36-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Bellotto_New_Town_Market_Square.jpg/220px-Bellotto_New_Town_Market_Square.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bellotto_New_Town_Market_Square.jpg) [Warsaw New Town](/wiki/Warsaw_New_Town "Warsaw New Town") in 1778. Painted by [Bernardo Bellotto](/wiki/Bernardo_Bellotto "Bernardo Bellotto").

The reign of [Augustus II](/wiki/Augustus_II_the_Strong "Augustus II the Strong") and [Augustus III](/wiki/Augustus_III_of_Poland "Augustus III of Poland") was a time of great development for Warsaw, which turned into an early-capitalist city. The [Saxon](/wiki/Saxony "Saxony") monarchs employed many German architects, sculptors and engineers, who rebuilt the city in a style similar to [Dresden](/wiki/Dresden "Dresden"). The year 1727 marked the opening of the [Saxon Garden](/wiki/Saxon_Garden "Saxon Garden") in Warsaw, the first publicly accessible park.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-37)^ The [Załuski Library](/wiki/Za%C5%82uski_Library "Załuski Library"), the first Polish public library and the largest at the time, was founded in 1747.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-38)^ [Stanisław II Augustus](/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_II_Augustus "Stanisław II Augustus"), who remodelled the interior of the [Royal Castle](/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw "Royal Castle, Warsaw"), also made Warsaw a centre of culture and the arts.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-Rozek-39)^^[\[38\]](#cite_note-Stanley-40)^ He extended the [Royal Baths Park](/wiki/Royal_Baths_Park "Royal Baths Park") and ordered the construction or refurbishment of numerous palaces, mansions and richly-decorated tenements. This earned Warsaw the nickname *Paris of the North* .^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Golna-41)^{#cite_ref-Golna_41-0}

Warsaw remained the capital of the [Polish--Lithuanian Commonwealth](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth "Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth") until 1795 when it was annexed by the [Kingdom of Prussia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia "Kingdom of Prussia") in the third and final [partition of Poland](/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland "Partitions of Poland");^[\[40\]](#cite_note-42)^ it subsequently became the capital of the province of [South Prussia](/wiki/South_Prussia "South Prussia"). During this time, [Louis XVIII of France](/wiki/Louis_XVIII_of_France "Louis XVIII of France") spent his exile in Warsaw under the pseudonym *Comte de Lille* .^[\[41\]](#cite_note-43)^{#cite_ref-43}  

### 1800--1939 {#1800.E2.80.931939}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: 1800–1939")\]

Warsaw was made the capital of a newly created [French client state](/wiki/List_of_French_client_states "List of French client states"), known as the [Duchy of Warsaw](/wiki/Duchy_of_Warsaw "Duchy of Warsaw"), after a portion of Poland's territory was liberated from Prussia, Russia and Austria by [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon_I "Napoleon I") in 1806.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-history-30)^ Following Napoleon's defeat and exile, the 1815 [Congress of Vienna](/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna "Congress of Vienna") assigned Warsaw to [Congress Poland](/wiki/Congress_Poland "Congress Poland"), a [constitutional monarchy](/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy "Constitutional monarchy") within the easternmost sector (or partition) under a [personal union](/wiki/Personal_union "Personal union") with [Imperial Russia](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire").^[\[28\]](#cite_note-history-30)^ The Royal University of Warsaw was established in 1816.{#cite_ref-history_30-7}

With the violation of the [Polish constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland "Constitution of the Kingdom of Poland"), the 1830 [November Uprising](/wiki/November_Uprising "November Uprising") broke out against foreign influence. The Polish-Russian war of 1831 ended in the uprising's defeat and in the curtailment of Congress Poland's autonomy.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-history-30)^ On 27 February 1861, a Warsaw crowd protesting against Russian control over Congress Poland was fired upon by Russian troops.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-Naliwajek-44)^^[\[43\]](#cite_note-obrien-45)^ Five people were killed. The Underground [Polish National Government](/wiki/Polish_National_Government_(January_Uprising) "Polish National Government (January Uprising)") resided in Warsaw during the [January Uprising](/wiki/January_Uprising "January Uprising") in 1863--64.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-obrien-45)^{#cite_ref-obrien_45-1}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Warszawa._Ul._Marszalkowska._191-_%2867220595%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Warszawa._Ul._Marszalkowska._191-_%2867220595%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warszawa._Ul._Marszalkowska._191-_(67220595)_(cropped).jpg)  
[Marszałkowska Street](/wiki/Marsza%C5%82kowska_Street,_Warsaw "Marszałkowska Street, Warsaw"), 1912  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Warszawa%2C_Filharmonia._ante_1906_%2812981792%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Warszawa%2C_Filharmonia._ante_1906_%2812981792%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warszawa,_Filharmonia._ante_1906_(12981792)_(cropped).jpg)  
[National Philharmonic](/wiki/National_Philharmonic_in_Warsaw "National Philharmonic in Warsaw"), before 1906

Warsaw flourished throughout the 19th century under Mayor [Sokrates Starynkiewicz](/wiki/Sokrates_Starynkiewicz "Sokrates Starynkiewicz") (1875--92), who was appointed by [Alexander III](/wiki/Alexander_III_of_Russia "Alexander III of Russia"). Under Starynkiewicz Warsaw saw its first water and sewer systems designed and built by the English engineer [William Lindley](/wiki/William_Lindley "William Lindley") and his son, [William Heerlein Lindley](/wiki/William_Heerlein_Lindley "William Heerlein Lindley"), as well as the expansion and modernisation of trams, street lighting, and gas infrastructure.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-history-30)^ Between 1850 and 1882, the population grew by 134% to 383,000 as a result of rapid urbanisation and industrialisation. Many migrated from surrounding rural Masovian towns and villages to the city for employment opportunities. The western borough of [Wola](/wiki/Wola "Wola") was transformed from an agricultural periphery occupied mostly by small farms and windmills (mills being the namesake of Wola's central neighbourhood [Młynów](/wiki/M%C5%82yn%C3%B3w,_Warsaw "Młynów, Warsaw")) to an industrial and manufacturing centre.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-46)^ [Metallurgical](/wiki/Metallurgy "Metallurgy"), textile and glassware factories were commonplace, with chimneys dominating the westernmost skyline.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-47)^{#cite_ref-47}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Filtry_Warszawskie_przy_ul._Koszykowej_81_w_Warszawie%2C_Hala_Filtr%C3%B3w_Powolnych.jpg/220px-Filtry_Warszawskie_przy_ul._Koszykowej_81_w_Warszawie%2C_Hala_Filtr%C3%B3w_Powolnych.jpg)](/wiki/File:Filtry_Warszawskie_przy_ul._Koszykowej_81_w_Warszawie,_Hala_Filtr%C3%B3w_Powolnych.jpg) [Water Filters](/wiki/Warsaw_Water_Filters "Warsaw Water Filters"), designed by [William Lindley](/wiki/William_Lindley "William Lindley") and finished in 1886

Like [London](/wiki/London "London"), Warsaw's population was subjected to income segmentation. Gentrification of inner suburbs forced poorer residents to move across the river into [Praga](/wiki/Praga "Praga") or [Powiśle](/wiki/Powi%C5%9Ble,_Warsaw "Powiśle, Warsaw") and [Solec](/wiki/Solec,_Warsaw "Solec, Warsaw") districts, similar to the [East End of London](/wiki/East_End_of_London "East End of London") and [London Docklands](/wiki/London_Docklands "London Docklands").^[\[46\]](#cite_note-48)^ Poorer religious and ethnic minorities, such as the Jews, settled in the crowded parts of northern Warsaw, in [Muranów](/wiki/Muran%C3%B3w "Muranów").^[\[47\]](#cite_note-49)^ The [Imperial Census](/wiki/Russian_Empire_Census "Russian Empire Census") of 1897 recorded 626,000 people living in Warsaw, making it the third-largest city of the Empire after [St. Petersburg](/wiki/St._Petersburg "St. Petersburg") and Moscow as well as the largest city in the region.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-50)^ Grand architectural complexes and structures were also erected in the city centre, including the [Warsaw Philharmonic](/wiki/Warsaw_Philharmonic "Warsaw Philharmonic"), the [Church of the Holiest Saviour](/wiki/Church_of_the_Holiest_Saviour "Church of the Holiest Saviour") and tenements along [Marszałkowska Street](/wiki/Marsza%C5%82kowska_Street "Marszałkowska Street").{#cite_ref-50}

During [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), Warsaw was occupied by Germany from 4 August 1915 until November 1918. The [Armistice of 11 November 1918](/wiki/Armistice_of_11_November_1918 "Armistice of 11 November 1918") concluded that defeated Germany is to withdraw from all foreign areas, which included Warsaw.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-Wandycz-51)^ Germany did so, and underground leader [Józef Piłsudski](/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski "Józef Piłsudski") returned to Warsaw on the same day which marked the beginning of the [Second Polish Republic](/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic "Second Polish Republic"), the first truly sovereign Polish state after 1795. In the course of the [Polish--Soviet War](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Soviet_War "Polish–Soviet War") (1919--1921), the 1920 [Battle of Warsaw](/wiki/Battle_of_Warsaw_(1920) "Battle of Warsaw (1920)") was fought on the eastern outskirts of the city. Poland successfully defended the capital, stopped the brunt of the Bolshevik [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") and temporarily halted the "[export of the communist revolution](/wiki/Export_of_revolution "Export of revolution")" to other parts of Europe.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-Zamoyski-52)^{#cite_ref-Zamoyski_52-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Ulica_Marsza%C5%82kowska_r%C3%B3g_Kredytowej_w_Warszawie_1908.jpg/220px-Ulica_Marsza%C5%82kowska_r%C3%B3g_Kredytowej_w_Warszawie_1908.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ulica_Marsza%C5%82kowska_r%C3%B3g_Kredytowej_w_Warszawie_1908.jpg) [Boguslaw Herse Fashion House](/wiki/Boguslaw_Herse_Fashion_House "Boguslaw Herse Fashion House"), a renowned department store during the [interbellum period](/wiki/Interwar_period "Interwar period")

The interwar period (1918--1939) was a time of major development in the city's infrastructure. New [modernist](/wiki/Modernism "Modernism") housing estates were built in [Mokotów](/wiki/Mokot%C3%B3w "Mokotów") to de-clutter the densely populated inner suburbs. In 1921, Warsaw's total area was estimated at only 124.7 km^2^ with 1 million inhabitants--over 8,000 people/km^2^ made Warsaw more densely populated than contemporary London.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-53)^ The [Średnicowy Bridge](/wiki/%C5%9Arednicowy_Bridge "Średnicowy Bridge") was constructed for railway (1921--1931), connecting both parts of the city across the [Vistula](/wiki/Vistula "Vistula"). [Warszawa Główna railway station](/wiki/Warszawa_G%C5%82%C3%B3wna_railway_station "Warszawa Główna railway station") (1932--1939) was not completed due to the outbreak of the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War").{#cite_ref-53}

[Stefan Starzyński](/wiki/Stefan_Starzy%C5%84ski "Stefan Starzyński") was the [Mayor of Warsaw](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Warsaw "List of mayors of Warsaw") between 1934 and 1939.  

### Second World War {#Second_World_War}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Second World War")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Warsaw_Old_Town_1945.jpg/226px-Warsaw_Old_Town_1945.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warsaw_Old_Town_1945.jpg)  
Ruins of Old Town.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Ruiny_getta_warszawskiego_w_drugiej_po%C5%82owie_lat_40.jpg/198px-Ruiny_getta_warszawskiego_w_drugiej_po%C5%82owie_lat_40.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ruiny_getta_warszawskiego_w_drugiej_po%C5%82owie_lat_40.jpg)  
Ruins of Northern District.  
After the [destruction of Warsaw](/wiki/Destruction_of_Warsaw "Destruction of Warsaw") over 85% of the buildings lay in ruins, including the [Old Town](/wiki/Old_Town,_Warsaw "Old Town, Warsaw") and the [Royal Castle](/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw "Royal Castle, Warsaw").^[\[52\]](#cite_note-last_glimpse-54)^

After the German [Invasion of Poland](/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland "Invasion of Poland") on 1 September 1939 started the Second World War, Warsaw [was defended](/wiki/Siege_of_Warsaw_(1939) "Siege of Warsaw (1939)") until 27 September. Central Poland, including Warsaw, came under the rule of the [General Government](/wiki/General_Government "General Government"), a German [Nazi](/wiki/Nazism "Nazism") colonial administration. All higher education institutions were immediately closed and Warsaw's entire Jewish population -- several hundred thousand, some 30% of the city -- were herded into the [Warsaw Ghetto](/wiki/Warsaw_Ghetto "Warsaw Ghetto").^[\[53\]](#cite_note-ushmm-55)^ In July 1942, the Jews of the Warsaw Ghetto began to be deported en masse to the [Aktion Reinhard](/wiki/Aktion_Reinhard "Aktion Reinhard") extermination camps, particularly [Treblinka](/wiki/Treblinka "Treblinka").^[\[53\]](#cite_note-ushmm-55)^ The city would become the centre of urban resistance to Nazi rule in occupied Europe.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-Snyder-56)^ When the order came to annihilate the ghetto as part of [Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler")'s "[Final Solution](/wiki/Final_Solution "Final Solution")" on 19 April 1943, Jewish fighters launched the [Warsaw Ghetto Uprising](/wiki/Warsaw_Ghetto_Uprising "Warsaw Ghetto Uprising").^[\[55\]](#cite_note-ghettouprising-57)^ Despite being heavily outgunned and outnumbered, the ghetto held out for almost a month.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-ghettouprising-57)^ When the fighting ended, almost all survivors were massacred, with only a few managing to escape or hide.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-ghettouprising-57)^^[\[56\]](#cite_note-aish-58)^{#cite_ref-aish_58-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Powstanie_Warszawskie_film_Joachmiczyk.jpg/190px-Powstanie_Warszawskie_film_Joachmiczyk.jpg)](/wiki/File:Powstanie_Warszawskie_film_Joachmiczyk.jpg) The [Warsaw Uprising](/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising "Warsaw Uprising") took place in 1944. The [Polish Home Army](/wiki/Armia_Krajowa "Armia Krajowa") attempted to liberate Warsaw from the Germans before the arrival of the [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army").^[\[57\]](#cite_note-britannica-59)^

By July 1944, the [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") was deep into Polish territory and pursuing the Nazis toward Warsaw.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-uprising-60)^ The [Polish government-in-exile](/wiki/Polish_government-in-exile "Polish government-in-exile") in London gave orders to the underground [Home Army (AK)](/wiki/Armia_Krajowa "Armia Krajowa") to try to seize control of Warsaw before the Red Army arrived. Thus, on 1 August 1944, as the Red Army was nearing the city, the [Warsaw uprising](/wiki/Warsaw_uprising "Warsaw uprising") began.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-uprising-60)^ The armed struggle, planned to last 48 hours, was partially successful, however, it went on for 63 days. Eventually, the Home Army fighters and civilians assisting them were forced to capitulate.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-uprising-60)^ They were transported to [PoW](/wiki/Prisoner_of_war "Prisoner of war") camps in Germany, while the entire civilian population was expelled.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-uprising-60)^ Polish civilian deaths are estimated at between 150,000 and 200,000.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-Borkiewicz-61)^{#cite_ref-Borkiewicz_61-0}

Hitler, ignoring the agreed terms of the capitulation, ordered the [entire city to be razed to the ground](/wiki/Destruction_of_Warsaw "Destruction of Warsaw") and the library and museum collections taken to Germany or burned.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-uprising-60)^ Monuments and government buildings were blown up by special German troops known as *Verbrennungs- und Vernichtungskommando* ("Burning and Destruction Detachments").^[\[58\]](#cite_note-uprising-60)^ About 85% of the city was destroyed, including the historic Old Town and the Royal Castle.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-warsawuprising_com-62)^{#cite_ref-warsawuprising_com_62-0}

On 17 January 1945 -- after the beginning of the [Vistula--Oder Offensive](/wiki/Vistula%E2%80%93Oder_Offensive "Vistula–Oder Offensive") of the [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") -- Soviet troops and Polish troops of the [First Polish Army](/wiki/First_Polish_Army_(1944-1945) "First Polish Army (1944-1945)") entered the ruins of Warsaw, and liberated Warsaw's suburbs from German occupation.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-Adamczyk-63)^ The city was swiftly freed by the Soviet Army, which rapidly advanced towards [Łódź](/wiki/%C5%81%C3%B3d%C5%BA "Łódź"), as German forces regrouped at a more westward position.{#cite_ref-Adamczyk_63-0}  

### 1945--1989 {#1945.E2.80.931989}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: 1945–1989")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Bw._Aleksandra_w_Warszawie_przed_1939.jpg/200px-Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Bw._Aleksandra_w_Warszawie_przed_1939.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Bw._Aleksandra_w_Warszawie_przed_1939.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Bw._Aleksandra_w_Warszawie_2022a.jpg/200px-Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Bw._Aleksandra_w_Warszawie_2022a.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Bw._Aleksandra_w_Warszawie_2022a.jpg)  
[St. Alexander's Church](/wiki/St._Alexander%27s_Church,_Warsaw "St. Alexander's Church, Warsaw") at [Three Crosses Square](/wiki/Three_Crosses_Square "Three Crosses Square") before the war and today - many monuments were rebuilt in a changed form

In 1945, after the bombings, revolts, fighting, and demolition had ended, most of Warsaw lay in ruins. The area of the former ghetto was razed to the ground, with only a sea of rubble remaining. The immense destruction prompted a temporary transfer of the new government and its officials to [Łódź](/wiki/%C5%81%C3%B3d%C5%BA "Łódź"), which became the transitional seat of power. Nevertheless, Warsaw officially resumed its role as the capital of Poland and the country's centre of political and economic life.

After World War II, the "Bricks for Warsaw" campaign was initiated and large prefabricated housing projects were erected in Warsaw to address the major housing shortage. [Plattenbau](/wiki/Plattenbau "Plattenbau")-styled apartment buildings were seen as a solution to avoid Warsaw's former density problem and to create more green spaces. Some of the buildings from the 19th century that had survived in a reasonably reconstructible form were nonetheless demolished in the 1950s and 1960s, like the [Kronenberg Palace](/wiki/Leopold_Stanis%C5%82aw_Kronenberg "Leopold Stanisław Kronenberg").^[\[62\]](#cite_note-64)^^[\[63\]](#cite_note-65)^ The [Śródmieście](/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcie,_Warsaw "Śródmieście, Warsaw") (central) region's urban system was completely reshaped; former cobblestone streets were [asphalted](/wiki/Asphalt_concrete "Asphalt concrete") and significantly widened for traffic use. Many notable streets such as Gęsia, Nalewki and Wielka disappeared as a result of these changes and some were split in half due to the construction of [Plac Defilad](/wiki/Parade_Square "Parade Square") (Parade Square), one of the largest of its kind in Europe.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-66)^{#cite_ref-66}

Much of the central district was also designated for future skyscrapers. The 237-metre [Palace of Culture and Science](/wiki/Palace_of_Culture_and_Science,_Warsaw "Palace of Culture and Science, Warsaw") resembling New York's [Empire State Building](/wiki/Empire_State_Building "Empire State Building") was built as a gift from the Soviet Union.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-67)^ Warsaw's urban landscape is one of modern and contemporary architecture.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-68)^ Despite wartime destruction and post-war remodelling, many of the historic streets, buildings, and churches were restored to their original form.{#cite_ref-68}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/A_Kult%C3%BAra_%C3%A9s_Tudom%C3%A1ny_Palot%C3%A1ja._Fortepan_75020_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-A_Kult%C3%BAra_%C3%A9s_Tudom%C3%A1ny_Palot%C3%A1ja._Fortepan_75020_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_Kult%C3%BAra_%C3%A9s_Tudom%C3%A1ny_Palot%C3%A1ja._Fortepan_75020_(cropped).jpg) [Palace of Culture and Science](/wiki/Palace_of_Culture_and_Science "Palace of Culture and Science") in 1960.

[John Paul II](/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II "Pope John Paul II")'s visits to his native country in 1979 and 1983 brought support to the budding ["Solidarity" movement](/wiki/Solidarity_(Polish_trade_union) "Solidarity (Polish trade union)") and encouraged the growing [anti-communist](/wiki/Anti-communism "Anti-communism") fervor there.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-destination-69)^ In 1979, less than a year after becoming pope, John Paul celebrated Mass in [Victory Square](/wiki/Pi%C5%82sudski_Square "Piłsudski Square") in Warsaw and ended his sermon with a call to "renew the face" of Poland.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-destination-69)^ These words were meaningful for Varsovians and Poles who understood them as the incentive for liberal-democratic reforms.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-destination-69)^{#cite_ref-destination_69-2}  

### 1989--present {#1989.E2.80.93present}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: 1989–present")\]

In 1995, the [Warsaw Metro](/wiki/Warsaw_Metro "Warsaw Metro") opened with a single line.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-70)^ A second line was opened in March 2015.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-71)^ On 28 September 2022, three new Warsaw metro stations were opened, increasing the number of Warsaw Metro stations to 36 and its length to 38.3 kilometers.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-72)^ In February 2023, Warsaw's mayor, [Rafał Trzaskowski](/wiki/Rafa%C5%82_Trzaskowski "Rafał Trzaskowski"), announced plans to more than double the size of the city's metro system by 2050.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-73)^{#cite_ref-73}

With the entry of Poland into the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") in 2004,^[\[72\]](#cite_note-74)^^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit)^ Warsaw is experiencing a large economic boom.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-polandtrade-75)^ The opening fixture of [UEFA Euro 2012](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012 "UEFA Euro 2012") took place in Warsaw^[\[74\]](#cite_note-poland2012-76)^ and the city also hosted the [2013 United Nations Climate Change Conference](/wiki/2013_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference "2013 United Nations Climate Change Conference")^[\[75\]](#cite_note-77)^ and the [2016 NATO Summit](/wiki/2016_Warsaw_summit "2016 Warsaw summit").^[\[76\]](#cite_note-78)^ As of August 2022, Warsaw had received around 180,000 refugees from Ukraine, because of the [2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine"). The amount means a tenth of the Polish capital's population of 1.8 million --- the second-largest single group of Ukrainian refugees.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-79)^{#cite_ref-79}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Geography")\]  

### Location and topography {#Location_and_topography}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Location and topography")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Warsaw_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-06-01.jpg/220px-Warsaw_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-06-01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warsaw_by_Sentinel-2,_2020-06-01.jpg) Warsaw, as seen from the [European Space Agency (ESA)](/wiki/European_Space_Agency "European Space Agency") [Sentinel-2](/wiki/Sentinel-2 "Sentinel-2")

Warsaw lies in east-central Poland about 300 km (190 mi) from the [Carpathian Mountains](/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains "Carpathian Mountains") and about 260 km (160 mi) from the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea"), 523 km (325 mi) east of Berlin, Germany.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-80)^ The city straddles the [Vistula](/wiki/Vistula "Vistula") River. It is located in the heartland of the [Masovian Plain](/wiki/Masovian_Plain "Masovian Plain"), and its average elevation is 100 m (330 ft) above sea level. The highest point on the West side of the city lies at a height of 115.7 m (380 ft) ("Redutowa" bus depot, district of Wola), on the East side -- 122.1 m (401 ft) ("Groszówka" estate, district of Wesoła, by the eastern border). The lowest point lies at a height 75.6 m (248 ft) (at the right bank of the Vistula, by the eastern border of Warsaw). There are some hills (mostly artificial) located within the confines of the city -- e.g. Warsaw Uprising Hill (121 m (397 ft)) and Szczęśliwice hill (138 m (453 ft) -- the highest point of Warsaw in general).{#cite_ref-80}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Plac_Grzybowski_noc%C4%85.jpg/220px-Plac_Grzybowski_noc%C4%85.jpg)](/wiki/File:Plac_Grzybowski_noc%C4%85.jpg) View of [Grzybowski Square](/wiki/Grzybowski_Square "Grzybowski Square") in the [central district of Warsaw](/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcie,_Warsaw "Śródmieście, Warsaw"). The city is located on the mostly flat [Masovian Plain](/wiki/Masovian_Plain "Masovian Plain"), but the city centre is at a higher elevation than the suburbs.

Warsaw is located on two main geomorphologic formations: the plain moraine plateau and the Vistula Valley with its asymmetrical pattern of different terraces. The Vistula River is the specific axis of Warsaw, which divides the city into two parts, left and right. The left one is situated both on the [moraine](/wiki/Moraine "Moraine") plateau (10 to 25 m (33 to 82 ft) above Vistula level) and on the Vistula terraces (max. 6.5 m (21 ft) above Vistula level). The significant element of the relief, in this part of Warsaw, is the edge of moraine plateau called Warsaw Escarpment. It is 20 to 25 m (66 to 82 ft) high in the Old Town and Central district and about 10 m (33 ft) in the north and south of Warsaw. It goes through the city and plays an important role as a landmark.

The plain moraine plateau has only a few natural and artificial ponds and also groups of [clay pits](/wiki/Clay_pit "Clay pit"). The pattern of the Vistula terraces is asymmetrical. The left side consists mainly of two levels: the highest one contains former flooded terraces and the lowest one is the floodplain terrace. The contemporary flooded terrace still has visible valleys and ground [depressions](/wiki/Depression_(geology) "Depression (geology)") with water systems coming from the old Vistula -- riverbed. They consist of still quite natural streams and lakes as well as the pattern of drainage ditches. The right side of Warsaw has a different pattern of geomorphological forms. There are several levels of the Vistula plain terraces (flooded as well as formerly flooded), and only a small part is a not-so-visible moraine escarpment. [Aeolian](/wiki/Aeolian_processes "Aeolian processes") sand with a number of dunes parted by [peat](/wiki/Peat "Peat") swamps or small ponds cover the highest terrace. These are mainly forested areas ([pine forest](/wiki/Temperate_coniferous_forest "Temperate coniferous forest")).  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Climate")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Jesie%C5%84_w_%C5%82azienkach_kr%C3%B3lewskich_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Jesie%C5%84_w_%C5%82azienkach_kr%C3%B3lewskich_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jesie%C5%84_w_%C5%82azienkach_kr%C3%B3lewskich_-_panoramio.jpg) Autumn in Warsaw's [Royal Baths](/wiki/%C5%81azienki_Park "Łazienki Park")

Warsaw experiences an [oceanic](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Cfb)* or [humid continental](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Dfb)* climate, depending on the isotherm used;^[\[79\]](#cite_note-81)^^[\[80\]](#cite_note-82)^ although the city used to be humid continental regardless of isotherm prior to the recent effect of [climate change](/wiki/Climate_change "Climate change") and the city's [urban heat island](/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island").^[\[81\]](#cite_note-:0-83)^^[\[82\]](#cite_note-84)^^[\[83\]](#cite_note-85)^^[\[84\]](#cite_note-noaa-86)^ Meanwhile, by the genetic climate classification of [Wincenty Okołowicz](/wiki/Wincenty_Oko%C5%82owicz "Wincenty Okołowicz"), it has a [temperate](/wiki/Temperate_climate "Temperate climate") "fusion" climate, with both oceanic and continental features.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-87)^{#cite_ref-87}

The city has cold, sometimes snowy, cloudy winters, and warm, relatively sunny but frequently stormy summers. Spring and autumn can be unpredictable, highly prone to sudden weather changes; however, temperatures are usually mild, especially around May and September.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-:0-83)^ The daily average temperature ranges between −1.5 °C (29 °F) in January and 19.7 °C (67.5 °F) in July and the mean year temperature is 9.0 °C (48.2 °F). Temperatures may reach 30 °C (86 °F) in the summer, although the effects of hot weather are usually offset by relatively low dew points and large diurnal temperature differences. Warsaw is Europe's sixth driest major city (driest in [Central Europe](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe")), with yearly rainfall averaging 550 mm (22 in), the wettest month being July.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-88)^{#cite_ref-88}

Cityscape {#Cityscape}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Cityscape")\]  

### Urbanism and architecture {#Urbanism_and_architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Urbanism and architecture")\]  
Main article: [Architecture of Warsaw](/wiki/Architecture_of_Warsaw "Architecture of Warsaw")

Warsaw's long and eclectic history left a noticeable mark on its architecture and urban form. Unlike most Polish cities, Warsaw's cityscape is mostly [contemporary](/wiki/Contemporary_architecture "Contemporary architecture") -- modern glass buildings are towering above older historical edifices which is a common feature of [North American](/wiki/North_America "North America") metropolises. Warsaw is among the European cities with the highest number of skyscrapers and is home to [European Union's tallest building](/wiki/Varso "Varso"). Skyscrapers are mostly centered around the [Śródmieście](/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcie,_Warsaw "Śródmieście, Warsaw") district, with many located in the commercial district of [Wola](/wiki/Wola "Wola"). A [concentric zone pattern](/wiki/Concentric_zone_model "Concentric zone model") emerged within the last decades; the majority of Warsaw's residents live outside the commercial city centre and commute by [metro](/wiki/Warsaw_metro "Warsaw metro"), bus or tram.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-auto-104)^ [Tenements](/wiki/Tenement "Tenement") and apartments in the central neighbourhoods are often reserved for commercial activity or temporary (tourist, student) accommodation. The nearest residential zones are predominantly located on the outskirts of the inner borough, in [Ochota](/wiki/Ochota "Ochota"), [Mokotów](/wiki/Mokot%C3%B3w "Mokotów") and [Żoliborz](/wiki/%C5%BBoliborz "Żoliborz") or along the [Vistula](/wiki/Vistula "Vistula") in [Powiśle](/wiki/Powi%C5%9Ble,_Warsaw "Powiśle, Warsaw").^[\[102\]](#cite_note-auto-104)^{#cite_ref-auto_104-1}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Interior_of_the_Main_Building_of_the_Warsaw_University_of_Technology%2C_Poland%2C_04.jpg/280px-Interior_of_the_Main_Building_of_the_Warsaw_University_of_Technology%2C_Poland%2C_04.jpg)](/wiki/File:Interior_of_the_Main_Building_of_the_Warsaw_University_of_Technology,_Poland,_04.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Interiors_of_Z%C5%82ote_Tarasy%2C_Warsaw%2C_Poland%2C_2019%2C_04.jpg/280px-Interiors_of_Z%C5%82ote_Tarasy%2C_Warsaw%2C_Poland%2C_2019%2C_04.jpg)](/wiki/File:Interiors_of_Z%C5%82ote_Tarasy,_Warsaw,_Poland,_2019,_04.jpg)  
Old and new--[Warsaw Polytechnic](/wiki/Warsaw_University_of_Technology "Warsaw University of Technology") courtyard (above) and [Złote Tarasy](/wiki/Z%C5%82ote_Tarasy "Złote Tarasy") mall (below)

A seat of [Polish monarchs](/wiki/Polish_monarchs "Polish monarchs") since the end of the 16th century, Warsaw remained a small city with only privately owned palaces, mansions, villas and several streets of townhouses. These displayed a richness of color and architectonic details. The finest German, Italian and Dutch architects were employed, among them [Tylman van Gameren](/wiki/Tylman_van_Gameren "Tylman van Gameren"), [Andreas Schlüter](/wiki/Andreas_Schl%C3%BCter "Andreas Schlüter"), [Jakub Fontana](/wiki/Jakub_Fontana "Jakub Fontana"), and [Enrico Marconi](/wiki/Enrico_Marconi "Enrico Marconi").^[\[103\]](#cite_note-105)^ The buildings situated in the vicinity of the [Warsaw Old Town](/wiki/Warsaw_Old_Town "Warsaw Old Town") represent nearly every European architectural style and [historical period](/wiki/List_of_time_periods "List of time periods"). Warsaw has excellent examples of architecture from the [Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic architecture"), [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance"), [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") and [Neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") periods, all of which are located within walking distance of the centre. This architectural richness has led to Warsaw being described by some commentators as a "[Paris of the East](/wiki/Paris_of_the_East_(disambiguation) "Paris of the East (disambiguation)")".^[\[104\]](#cite_note-106)^{#cite_ref-106}

Gothic architecture is represented in the majestic churches but also at the [burgher](/wiki/Middle_class "Middle class") houses and fortifications. The most significant buildings are [St John's Cathedral](/wiki/St._John%27s_Cathedral,_Warsaw "St. John's Cathedral, Warsaw") (1390), a typical example of the so-called Masovian [Brick Gothic](/wiki/Brick_Gothic "Brick Gothic") style; [St Mary's Church](/wiki/Church_of_the_Visitation_of_the_Blessed_Virgin_Mary,_Warsaw "Church of the Visitation of the Blessed Virgin Mary, Warsaw") (1411); the Burbach [townhouse](/wiki/Townhouse "Townhouse") (14th century);^[\[105\]](#cite_note-107)^ Gunpowder Tower (after 1379); and [Royal Castle](/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw "Royal Castle, Warsaw")'s *Curia Maior* (1407--1410). The most notable examples of [Renaissance architecture](/wiki/Renaissance_architecture "Renaissance architecture") in the city are the house of the Baryczko merchant family (1562), a building called "The Negro" (early 17th century), and Salwator tenement (1632), all situated on the [Old Market Place](/wiki/Old_Town_Market_Place,_Warsaw "Old Town Market Place, Warsaw"). The most interesting examples of [Mannerist](/wiki/Mannerism "Mannerism") architecture are the [Royal Castle](/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw "Royal Castle, Warsaw") (1596--1619) and the [Jesuit Church](/wiki/Jesuit_Church,_Warsaw "Jesuit Church, Warsaw") (1609--1626).{#cite_ref-107}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Warszawa%2C_ul._Krakowskie_Przedmie%C5%9Bcie_42-44%2C_Karowa_22_20170516_001_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Warszawa%2C_ul._Krakowskie_Przedmie%C5%9Bcie_42-44%2C_Karowa_22_20170516_001_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warszawa,_ul._Krakowskie_Przedmie%C5%9Bcie_42-44,_Karowa_22_20170516_001_(cropped).jpg) [Hotel Bristol](/wiki/Hotel_Bristol,_Warsaw "Hotel Bristol, Warsaw") is a unique example of Warsaw's architectural heritage, combining [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") and [Neo-Renaissance](/wiki/Neo-Renaissance "Neo-Renaissance") designs.

[Baroque architecture](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture") arrived in Warsaw at the turn of the 16th and 17th centuries with the artists from the court circle of King [Sigismund III Vasa](/wiki/Sigismund_III_Vasa "Sigismund III Vasa") (the early Warsaw Baroque is referred to as Vasa Baroque). Among the first structures of the early Baroque, the most important are [St. Hyacinth's Church](/wiki/St._Hyacinth%27s_Church,_Warsaw "St. Hyacinth's Church, Warsaw") and [Sigismund's Column](/wiki/Sigismund%27s_Column "Sigismund's Column"), the first secular monument in the form of a column in modern history.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-108)^ At that time, part of the [Royal Castle](/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw "Royal Castle, Warsaw") was rebuilt in this style, the [Ujazdów Castle](/wiki/Ujazd%C3%B3w_Castle "Ujazdów Castle") and numerous Baroque palaces on the [Vistula](/wiki/Vistula "Vistula") escarpment were constructed. In the architecture of Catholic churches, the [Counter-Reformation](/wiki/Counter-Reformation "Counter-Reformation") type became a novelty, exemplified by the [Church of St. Anthony of Padua](/wiki/Church_of_St._Anthony_of_Padua,_Warsaw "Church of St. Anthony of Padua, Warsaw"), the [Carmelite Church](/wiki/Carmelite_Church,_Warsaw "Carmelite Church, Warsaw") and the [Holy Cross Church](/wiki/Holy_Cross_Church,_Warsaw "Holy Cross Church, Warsaw").^[\[107\]](#cite_note-barok-109)^{#cite_ref-barok_109-0}

Warsaw Baroque from the turn of the 17th and 18th centuries was characterized by building facades with a predominance of vertical elements close to the wall and numerous [ornaments](/wiki/Ornament_(art) "Ornament (art)"). The most important architect working in Warsaw at that time was [Tylman van Gameren](/wiki/Tylman_van_Gameren "Tylman van Gameren"). His projects include the [Krasiński Palace](/wiki/Krasi%C5%84ski_Palace "Krasiński Palace"), [Palace of the Four Winds](/wiki/Palace_of_the_Four_Winds "Palace of the Four Winds"), [Ostrogski Palace](/wiki/Ostrogski_Palace "Ostrogski Palace"), [Czapski Palace](/wiki/Czapski_Palace "Czapski Palace"), [Brühl Palace](/wiki/Br%C3%BChl_Palace,_Warsaw "Brühl Palace, Warsaw"), and [St. Kazimierz Church](/wiki/St._Kazimierz_Church "St. Kazimierz Church"). The most significant Baroque building of this period is the [Wilanów Palace](/wiki/Wilan%C3%B3w_Palace "Wilanów Palace"), built on the order of King [John III Sobieski](/wiki/John_III_Sobieski "John III Sobieski").^[\[107\]](#cite_note-barok-109)^{#cite_ref-barok_109-1}

The late Baroque era was the epoch of the [Saxon Kings](/wiki/Personal_union_of_Poland_and_Saxony "Personal union of Poland and Saxony") (1697--1763). During this time, three major spatial projects were realized: the 880-meter Piaseczyński Canal on the axis of [Ujazdów Castle](/wiki/Ujazd%C3%B3w_Castle "Ujazdów Castle"), the [Ujazdów Calvary](/wiki/Ujazd%C3%B3w_Avenue,_Warsaw "Ujazdów Avenue, Warsaw") and the [Saxon Axis](/wiki/Saxon_Axis "Saxon Axis"). The [Visitationist Church](/wiki/Visitationist_Church "Visitationist Church") also dates from this period.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-barok-109)^{#cite_ref-barok_109-2}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Warszawa%2C_ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Bw._Anny%2C_ch%C3%B3r_HDR.jpg/170px-Warszawa%2C_ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Bw._Anny%2C_ch%C3%B3r_HDR.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warszawa,_ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Bw._Anny,_ch%C3%B3r_HDR.jpg) Baroque organ at [St. Anne's Church](/wiki/St._Anne%27s_Church,_Warsaw "St. Anne's Church, Warsaw")

The [neoclassical architecture](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") began to be the main style in the capital's architecture in Warsaw in the second half of the 18th century thanks to King [Stanisław August Poniatowski](/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_August_Poniatowski "Stanisław August Poniatowski"). It can be described by the simplicity of the geometrical forms teamed with a great inspiration from the Roman period. The best-known architect who worked in Warsaw at the time was [Domenico Merlini](/wiki/Domenico_Merlini "Domenico Merlini"), who designed the [Palace on the Isle](/wiki/%C5%81azienki_Palace "Łazienki Palace"). Other significant buildings from this period include [Królikarnia](/wiki/Kr%C3%B3likarnia "Królikarnia"), [Holy Trinity Church](/wiki/Holy_Trinity_Church,_Warsaw "Holy Trinity Church, Warsaw"), [St. Anne's Church, Warsaw](/wiki/St._Anne%27s_Church,_Warsaw "St. Anne's Church, Warsaw").

Also in the first half of the 19th century, [neoclassicism](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") dominated the architecture of Warsaw. Old buildings were rebuilt and new ones were built in this style. The neoclassical revival affected all aspects of architecture; the most notable examples are the [Great Theater](/wiki/Great_Theatre,_Warsaw "Great Theatre, Warsaw"), buildings located at [Bank Square](/wiki/Plac_Bankowy,_Warsaw "Plac Bankowy, Warsaw"), headquarters of the [Warsaw Society of Friends of Sciences](/wiki/Warsaw_Society_of_Friends_of_Learning "Warsaw Society of Friends of Learning") ([Staszic Palace](/wiki/Staszic_Palace "Staszic Palace")), [St. Alexander's Church](/wiki/St._Alexander%27s_Church,_Warsaw "St. Alexander's Church, Warsaw"), the [Belweder](/wiki/Belweder "Belweder"). Many classicist tenement houses were built on Senatorska Street and along [Nowy Świat Street](/wiki/New_World_Street,_Warsaw "New World Street, Warsaw"). After the outbreak of the [November Uprising](/wiki/November_Uprising "November Uprising"), the [Warsaw Citadel](/wiki/Warsaw_Citadel "Warsaw Citadel") was constructed in the north of the city, and the [Saxon Palace](/wiki/Saxon_Palace "Saxon Palace") underwent a complete reconstruction, where the central body of the building was demolished and replaced by a monumental 11-bay [colonnade](/wiki/Colonnade "Colonnade").^[\[108\]](#cite_note-110)^{#cite_ref-110}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Kamienica_Wolfa_Krongolda_w_Warszawie_2023_%28cropped%292.jpg/145px-Kamienica_Wolfa_Krongolda_w_Warszawie_2023_%28cropped%292.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kamienica_Wolfa_Krongolda_w_Warszawie_2023_(cropped)2.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Gmach_Stowarzyszenia_Technik%C3%B3w_w_Warszawie_2021_%28cropped%29.jpg/159px-Gmach_Stowarzyszenia_Technik%C3%B3w_w_Warszawie_2021_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gmach_Stowarzyszenia_Technik%C3%B3w_w_Warszawie_2021_(cropped).jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Plac_Unii_Lubelskiej_widok_w_kierunku_wylotu_Bagateli_%28cropped%29.jpg/152px-Plac_Unii_Lubelskiej_widok_w_kierunku_wylotu_Bagateli_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Plac_Unii_Lubelskiej_widok_w_kierunku_wylotu_Bagateli_(cropped).jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Kamienica_Krasi%C5%84skich_w_Warszawie_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg/152px-Kamienica_Krasi%C5%84skich_w_Warszawie_2018_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kamienica_Krasi%C5%84skich_w_Warszawie_2018_(cropped).jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Kamienica_Wilhelma_Rakmana_w_Warszawie_2022.jpg/156px-Kamienica_Wilhelma_Rakmana_w_Warszawie_2022.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kamienica_Wilhelma_Rakmana_w_Warszawie_2022.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Varsovia_%28Polonia%29_Warszawa_%28Polska%29._152_%28cropped%29.jpg/148px-Varsovia_%28Polonia%29_Warszawa_%28Polska%29._152_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Varsovia_(Polonia)_Warszawa_(Polska)._152_(cropped).jpg)  
Multi-story tenement houses made up the majority of Warsaw's buildings at the end of the 19th century. Clockwise from upper left: Krongold Tenement House, Technicians' Association Building, Krasiński Tenement House, 15 [Foksal Street](/wiki/Foksal_Street "Foksal Street"), Rakman Tenement House, tenement houses at Union of Lublin Square.

In the mid-19th century, the industrial revolution reached Warsaw, leading to the mass use of iron as a building material. In 1845, the [Warsaw-Vienna Railway Station](/wiki/Warsaw%E2%80%93Vienna_railway "Warsaw–Vienna railway") was opened. Another important aspect of the developing city was ensuring access to water and sewage disposal. The first modern Warsaw water supply system was launched in 1855, designed by one of the most outstanding architects of that period -- [Enrico Marconi](/wiki/Enrico_Marconi "Enrico Marconi"), who designed also [All Saints Church](/wiki/All_Saints_Church,_Warsaw "All Saints Church, Warsaw"). The dynamic development of the railway became a factor that enabled equally dynamic development of Warsaw's industry. Among the establishments built at that time were the [Wedel factory](/wiki/E._Wedel "E. Wedel") and the extensive [Municipal Gasworks complex](/wiki/Warsaw_Gasworks_Museum "Warsaw Gasworks Museum").^[\[109\]](#cite_note-111)^{#cite_ref-111}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Prudential_w_Warszawie_2021.jpg/170px-Prudential_w_Warszawie_2021.jpg)](/wiki/File:Prudential_w_Warszawie_2021.jpg) [Prudential House](/wiki/Prudential_House "Prudential House"), built between 1931 and 1933 in the [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco") style, was the first [skyscraper](/wiki/Skyscraper "Skyscraper") in Poland and the second tallest building in Europe at the time of its completion.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-prudential-112)^

In the architecture of the 1920s, national historicism and other historical forms were dominant. [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco") forms also appeared, and towards the end of the decade, avant-garde functionalism emerged. The creation of urban plans for the capital of Poland can be traced back to 1916, when, after the [retreat of the Russians](/wiki/Great_Retreat_(Russia) "Great Retreat (Russia)") from Warsaw and the beginnings of the German occupation, the territories of the surrounding municipalities were annexed to the city. Even before Poland regained its independence, parallel to the creation of the administration of the future state, the first urban visions were emerging. These included, among others, the construction of a representative government district in the southern part of [Śródmieście](/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcie,_Warsaw "Śródmieście, Warsaw"). However, major changes in urban planning and the architectural landscape of the city only began in the mid-1920s. The forming state structures needed headquarters, leading to the construction of many monumental public buildings, including the [buildings of the Sejm and the Senate](/wiki/Sejm_and_Senate_Complex "Sejm and Senate Complex"), the [Ministry of Religious Affairs and Public Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Religious_Affairs_and_Public_Education_(Poland) "Ministry of Religious Affairs and Public Education (Poland)"), the [Ministry of Public Works](/wiki/Ministry_of_Infrastructure_(Poland) "Ministry of Infrastructure (Poland)"), the [National Museum](/wiki/Warsaw_National_Museum "Warsaw National Museum"), the [State Geological Institute](/wiki/Geological_Museum_of_the_State_Geological_Institute "Geological Museum of the State Geological Institute"), the State Agricultural Bank, the [Domestic Economy Bank](/wiki/Bank_Gospodarstwa_Krajowego "Bank Gospodarstwa Krajowego"), the directorate of the [Polish State Railways](/wiki/Polish_State_Railways "Polish State Railways"), the [Supreme Audit Office](/wiki/Supreme_Audit_Office_(Poland) "Supreme Audit Office (Poland)"), and the campus of the [Warsaw School of Economics](/wiki/SGH_Warsaw_School_of_Economics "SGH Warsaw School of Economics"). New districts were also established in [Żoliborz](/wiki/%C5%BBoliborz "Żoliborz"), [Ochota](/wiki/Ochota "Ochota"), and [Mokotów](/wiki/Mokot%C3%B3w "Mokotów"), often designed around a central square with radiating streets ([Narutowicz Square](/wiki/Narutowicz_Square "Narutowicz Square"), [Wilson Square](/wiki/Wilson_Square "Wilson Square")). Examples of new large urban projects are the Staszic and [Lubecki colonies](/wiki/Kolonia_Lubeckiego "Kolonia Lubeckiego") in [Ochota](/wiki/Ochota "Ochota").^[\[111\]](#cite_note-20s-113)^{#cite_ref-20s_113-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Ufficio_Primo%2C_Wsp%C3%B3lna_Street%2C_Warsaw%2C_Poland%2C_2019%2C_07.jpg/170px-Ufficio_Primo%2C_Wsp%C3%B3lna_Street%2C_Warsaw%2C_Poland%2C_2019%2C_07.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ufficio_Primo,_Wsp%C3%B3lna_Street,_Warsaw,_Poland,_2019,_07.jpg) The Government Presidium of the [Polish People's Republic](/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic "Polish People's Republic") from 1952 is an example of eclectic [modernism](/wiki/Modern_architecture "Modern architecture").

Exceptional examples of the [bourgeois](/wiki/Bourgeoisie "Bourgeoisie") architecture of the later periods were not restored by the [communist](/wiki/Communism "Communism") authorities after the war or were remodelled into a socialist realist style (like [Warsaw Philharmonic](/wiki/Warsaw_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Warsaw Philharmonic Orchestra") edifice originally inspired by [Palais Garnier](/wiki/Palais_Garnier "Palais Garnier") in [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris")). Despite that, the [Warsaw University of Technology](/wiki/Warsaw_University_of_Technology "Warsaw University of Technology") (Polytechnic) building.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-114)^ is the most interesting of the late 19th-century architecture. Some 19th-century industrial and brick workhouse buildings in the Praga district were restored, though many have been poorly maintained or demolished.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-115)^ Notable examples of post-war architecture include the [Palace of Culture and Science](/wiki/Palace_of_Culture_and_Science,_Warsaw "Palace of Culture and Science, Warsaw"), a [soc-realist](/wiki/Socialist_realism "Socialist realism") and [art deco](/wiki/Art_deco "Art deco") skyscraper based on the [Empire State Building](/wiki/Empire_State_Building "Empire State Building") in New York. The [Constitution Square](/wiki/Plac_Konstytucji "Plac Konstytucji") with its monumental [socialist realism](/wiki/Socialist_realism "Socialist realism") architecture (MDM estate) was modelled on the grand squares of Paris, London, Moscow and [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome").^[\[114\]](#cite_note-116)^ Italianate [tuscan-styled](/wiki/Tuscan_order "Tuscan order") colonnades based on those at [Piazza della Repubblica in Rome](/wiki/Piazza_della_Repubblica,_Rome "Piazza della Repubblica, Rome") were also erected on [Saviour Square](/wiki/Plac_Zbawiciela "Plac Zbawiciela").^[\[115\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}

[Contemporary architecture](/wiki/Contemporary_architecture "Contemporary architecture") in Warsaw is represented by the Metropolitan Office Building at [Pilsudski Square](/wiki/Pi%C5%82sudski_Square "Piłsudski Square") and [Varso](/wiki/Varso "Varso") tower, both by [Norman Foster](/wiki/Norman_Foster_(architect) "Norman Foster (architect)"),^[\[116\]](#cite_note-Metropolitan-118)^ [Warsaw University Library](/wiki/Warsaw_University_Library "Warsaw University Library") (BUW) by Marek Budzyński and Zbigniew Badowski, featuring a garden on its roof and view of the Vistula River, [Rondo 1](/wiki/Rondo_1 "Rondo 1") office building by [Skidmore, Owings \& Merrill](/wiki/Skidmore,_Owings_%26_Merrill "Skidmore, Owings & Merrill"), [Złota 44](/wiki/Z%C5%82ota_44 "Złota 44") residential skyscraper by [Daniel Libeskind](/wiki/Daniel_Libeskind "Daniel Libeskind"), [Museum of the History of Polish Jews](/wiki/Museum_of_the_History_of_Polish_Jews "Museum of the History of Polish Jews") by [Rainer Mahlamäki](/wiki/Rainer_Mahlam%C3%A4ki "Rainer Mahlamäki") and [Golden Terraces](/wiki/Z%C5%82ote_Tarasy "Złote Tarasy"), consisting of seven overlapping domes retail and business centre. Jointly with Moscow, Istanbul, Frankfurt, London, Paris and Rotterdam, Warsaw is one of the cities with the highest number of skyscrapers in Europe.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-scraper-119)^^[\[118\]](#cite_note-120)^{#cite_ref-120}  

### Landmarks {#Landmarks}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Landmarks")\]

Although contemporary Warsaw is a fairly young city compared to other European capitals, it has numerous [tourist attractions](/wiki/Tourist_attraction "Tourist attraction") and architectural monuments dating back centuries. Apart from the [Warsaw Old Town](/wiki/Warsaw_Old_Town "Warsaw Old Town") area, reconstructed after World War II, each borough has something to offer. Among the most notable landmarks of the Old Town are the [Royal Castle](/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw "Royal Castle, Warsaw"), [Sigismund's Column](/wiki/Sigismund%27s_Column "Sigismund's Column"), [Market Square](/wiki/Old_Town_Market_Place,_Warsaw "Old Town Market Place, Warsaw"), and the [Barbican](/wiki/Warsaw_Barbican "Warsaw Barbican").

Further south is the so-called [Royal Route](/wiki/Royal_Route,_Warsaw "Royal Route, Warsaw"), with many historical churches, [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture") and [Classicist](/wiki/Classicism "Classicism") palaces, most notably the [Presidential Palace](/wiki/Presidential_Palace,_Warsaw "Presidential Palace, Warsaw"), and the [University of Warsaw](/wiki/University_of_Warsaw "University of Warsaw") campus. The former royal residence of King [John III Sobieski](/wiki/John_III_Sobieski "John III Sobieski") at [Wilanów](/wiki/Wilan%C3%B3w_Palace "Wilanów Palace") is notable for its Baroque architecture and eloquent palatial garden.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-wilanow-palac-121)^{#cite_ref-wilanow-palac_121-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Zamek_Kr%C3%B3lewski_noc%C4%85_w_Warszawie_widok_od_strony_ogrod%C3%B3w_kr%C3%B3lewskich_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Zamek_Kr%C3%B3lewski_noc%C4%85_w_Warszawie_widok_od_strony_ogrod%C3%B3w_kr%C3%B3lewskich_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zamek_Kr%C3%B3lewski_noc%C4%85_w_Warszawie_widok_od_strony_ogrod%C3%B3w_kr%C3%B3lewskich_(cropped).jpg) [Royal Castle's](/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw "Royal Castle, Warsaw") [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture") façade

In many places in the city the [Jewish culture](/wiki/Jewish_culture "Jewish culture") and [history](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Poland "History of the Jews in Poland") resonates down through time.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-judaica-122)^ Among them the most notable are the [Jewish theater](/wiki/Jewish_Theatre,_Warsaw "Jewish Theatre, Warsaw"), the [Nożyk Synagogue](/wiki/No%C5%BCyk_Synagogue "Nożyk Synagogue"), [Janusz Korczak](/wiki/Janusz_Korczak "Janusz Korczak")'s Orphanage and the picturesque Próżna Street.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-judaica-122)^ The tragic pages of Warsaw's history are commemorated in places such as the [Monument to the Ghetto Heroes](/wiki/Monument_to_the_Ghetto_Heroes "Monument to the Ghetto Heroes"), the [Umschlagplatz](/wiki/Umschlagplatz_(Warsaw_Ghetto) "Umschlagplatz (Warsaw Ghetto)"), fragments of the ghetto wall on Sienna Street and a mound in memory of the [Jewish Combat Organization](/wiki/Jewish_Combat_Organization "Jewish Combat Organization").^[\[120\]](#cite_note-judaica-122)^{#cite_ref-judaica_122-2}

Many places commemorate the heroic history of Warsaw such as [Pawiak](/wiki/Pawiak "Pawiak"), a German [Gestapo](/wiki/Gestapo "Gestapo") prison now occupied by a [Mausoleum](/wiki/Mausoleum "Mausoleum") of Memory of [Martyrdom](/wiki/Martyr "Martyr") and a museum. The [Warsaw Citadel](/wiki/Warsaw_Citadel "Warsaw Citadel"), a 19th-century fortification built after the defeat of the [November Uprising](/wiki/November_Uprising "November Uprising"), was a place of martyrdom for the Poles. Another important monument, the statue of [Little Insurrectionist](/wiki/Ma%C5%82y_Powstaniec "Mały Powstaniec") located at the ramparts of the Old Town, commemorates the children who served as messengers and frontline troops in the Warsaw Uprising, while the [Warsaw Uprising Monument](/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising_Monument "Warsaw Uprising Monument") by Wincenty Kućma was erected in memory of the largest insurrection of World War II.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-heroic-123)^^[\[122\]](#cite_note-Montagu-124)^{#cite_ref-Montagu_124-0}

In Warsaw there are many places connected with the life and work of [Frédéric Chopin](/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Chopin "Frédéric Chopin") who was born near the city in [Żelazowa Wola](/wiki/%C5%BBelazowa_Wola "Żelazowa Wola"). The heart of the Polish composer is sealed inside Warsaw's [Holy Cross Church](/wiki/Holy_Cross_Church,_Warsaw "Holy Cross Church, Warsaw").^[\[123\]](#cite_note-Holy_Cross-125)^ During the summer time the [Chopin Statue](/wiki/Chopin_Statue,_Warsaw "Chopin Statue, Warsaw") in Łazienki Park is a place where pianists give concerts to the park audience.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-Chopin_Monument-126)^{#cite_ref-Chopin_Monument_126-0}

Also many references to [Marie Curie](/wiki/Marie_Curie "Marie Curie"), her work and her family can be found in Warsaw; Curie's birthplace at the [Warsaw New Town](/wiki/Warsaw_New_Town "Warsaw New Town"), the working places where she did her first scientific works^[\[125\]](#cite_note-aip1-127)^ and the [Radium Institute](/wiki/Curie_Institute_(Warsaw) "Curie Institute (Warsaw)") at Wawelska Street for the research and the treatment of which she founded in 1925.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-aip2-128)^{#cite_ref-aip2_128-0}
