### Cemeteries {#Cemeteries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Cemeteries")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_pw._%C5%9Bw._Karola_Boromeusza_na_tle_%C5%9Br%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcia_Warszawy.jpg/220px-Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_pw._%C5%9Bw._Karola_Boromeusza_na_tle_%C5%9Br%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcia_Warszawy.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_pw._%C5%9Bw._Karola_Boromeusza_na_tle_%C5%9Br%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcia_Warszawy.jpg) Church of [Saint Charles Borromeo](/wiki/Charles_Borromeo "Charles Borromeo") in [Stare Powązki](/wiki/Pow%C4%85zki_Cemetery "Powązki Cemetery")

The oldest [necropolis](/wiki/Necropolis "Necropolis") in Warsaw is [Stare Powązki](/wiki/Pow%C4%85zki_Cemetery "Powązki Cemetery"), established in 1790. It is one of Poland's national necropolises.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-cmentarze-129)^{#cite_ref-cmentarze_129-0}

The cemetery covers an area of 43 ha. On the day of consecration of the Powązki Cemetery, the foundation stone was laid for the construction of the church of [Saint Charles Borromeo](/wiki/Charles_Borromeo "Charles Borromeo"), designed by the royal architect [Domenico Merlini](/wiki/Domenico_Merlini "Domenico Merlini"). Catacombs were intended to be a prestigious resting place intended mainly for the nobles, such as [Michał Poniatowski](/wiki/Micha%C5%82_Jerzy_Poniatowski "Michał Jerzy Poniatowski"), [Hugo Kołłątaj](/wiki/Hugo_Ko%C5%82%C5%82%C4%85taj "Hugo Kołłątaj"), [Michał Kazimierz Ogiński](/wiki/Micha%C5%82_Kazimierz_Ogi%C5%84ski "Michał Kazimierz Ogiński"). Over a million people are buried at Stare Powązki. In the Avenue of Merit there are the graves of insurgents and soldiers, independence activists, writers, poets, scientists, artists and thinkers.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-130)^ The nearby [Powązki Military Cemetery](/wiki/Pow%C4%85zki_Military_Cemetery "Powązki Military Cemetery") was established in 1912 for soldiers stationed in Warsaw. After [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the cemetery became a burial place for people associated with the [Polish People's Republic](/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic "Polish People's Republic") - politicians, officials and military personnel.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-cmentarze-129)^{#cite_ref-cmentarze_129-1}

The complex of non-Roman Catholic cemeteries consists of [Evangelical--Augsburg Cemetery](/wiki/Evangelical%E2%80%93Augsburg_Cemetery,_Warsaw "Evangelical–Augsburg Cemetery, Warsaw"), [Evangelical Reformed Cemetery](/wiki/Evangelical_Reformed_Cemetery,_Warsaw "Evangelical Reformed Cemetery, Warsaw"), [Jewish Cemetery](/wiki/Jewish_Cemetery,_Warsaw "Jewish Cemetery, Warsaw"), [Orthodox Cemetery](/wiki/Orthodox_Cemetery,_Warsaw "Orthodox Cemetery, Warsaw") and Muslim Tatar Cemetery.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-cmentarze-129)^ Other significant Warsaw necropolises are: [Bródno Cemetery](/wiki/Br%C3%B3dno_Cemetery "Bródno Cemetery") [Warsaw Insurgents Cemetery](/wiki/Warsaw_Insurgents_Cemetery "Warsaw Insurgents Cemetery"), [Służew Old Cemetery](/wiki/S%C5%82u%C5%BCew_Old_Cemetery "Służew Old Cemetery"), [Służew New Cemetery](/wiki/S%C5%82u%C5%BCew_New_Cemetery "Służew New Cemetery"). There are two large municipal cemeteries in the city -- [Northern Communal Cemetery](/wiki/Northern_Communal_Cemetery "Northern Communal Cemetery") and Southern Communal Cemetery.{#cite_ref-cmentarze_129-2}  

### Memorials {#Memorials}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Memorials")\]

The city's symbol is the [mermaid](/wiki/Mermaid_of_Warsaw "Mermaid of Warsaw") placed in the capital's coat of arms. There are three mermaid monuments in Warsaw: one on the banks of the [Vistula](/wiki/Vistula "Vistula"), the second on the [Old Town Square](/wiki/Old_Town_Market_Place,_Warsaw "Old Town Market Place, Warsaw"), and the third in [Praga-Południe](/wiki/Praga-Po%C5%82udnie "Praga-Południe"). The oldest monument in Warsaw is the [Sigismund's Column](/wiki/Sigismund%27s_Column "Sigismund's Column"). It was built in 1644 according to the design of the Italians: Augustine Locci and Constantin Tencall. The King of Poland [Sigismund III Vasa](/wiki/Sigismund_III_Vasa "Sigismund III Vasa") stands on a 22-meter high tower, holding a cross and a sword in his hand. The monument was destroyed and rebuilt many times.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-pomniki-131)^{#cite_ref-pomniki_131-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Poland-00739_-_MORNING_TIME_-_Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier_%2830407658083%29.jpg/220px-Poland-00739_-_MORNING_TIME_-_Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier_%2830407658083%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Poland-00739_-_MORNING_TIME_-_Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier_(30407658083).jpg) [Tomb of the Unknown Soldier](/wiki/Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier,_Warsaw "Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, Warsaw"), once part of the [colonnade](/wiki/Colonnade "Colonnade") of [Saxon Palace](/wiki/Saxon_Palace "Saxon Palace")

Many monuments commemorate heroic and tragic moments in the history of Poland and Warsaw. [The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier](/wiki/Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier,_Warsaw "Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, Warsaw") located in [Piłsudski Square](/wiki/Pi%C5%82sudski_Square "Piłsudski Square") was built on the initiative of General [Władysław Sikorski](/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_Sikorski "Władysław Sikorski") in the arcades of the [Saxon Palace](/wiki/Saxon_Palace "Saxon Palace"). In 1925, the ashes of the unknown soldier who died during the [defense of Lviv](/wiki/Battle_of_Lemberg_(1918) "Battle of Lemberg (1918)") were placed under the colonnade, then urns with soil from 24 battlefields were buried here. Among the monuments related to the [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") are [Nike Monument](/wiki/Monument_to_the_Heroes_of_Warsaw "Monument to the Heroes of Warsaw") that commemorates the heroes of Warsaw from 1939 to 1945, [Monument to the Polish Underground State and Home Army](/wiki/Monument_to_the_Polish_Underground_State_and_Home_Army "Monument to the Polish Underground State and Home Army"), Monument to the [Little Insurrectionist](/wiki/Little_Insurrectionist "Little Insurrectionist") and [Warsaw Uprising Monument](/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising_Monument "Warsaw Uprising Monument") in front of the Supreme Court building at [Krasiński Square](/wiki/Krasi%C5%84ski_Square "Krasiński Square"). [Monument to the Ghetto Heroes](/wiki/Monument_to_the_Ghetto_Heroes "Monument to the Ghetto Heroes") commemorates the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising of 1943.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-132)^{#cite_ref-132}

In 1929, a [monument to Frédéric Chopin](/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Chopin_Monument,_Warsaw "Frédéric Chopin Monument, Warsaw") was constructed in the Royal [Łazienki Park](/wiki/%C5%81azienki_Park "Łazienki Park"). Every summer at its foot classical music concerts featuring world-famous pianists take place. Other important monuments are: [Adam Mickiewicz Monument](/wiki/Adam_Mickiewicz_Monument,_Warsaw "Adam Mickiewicz Monument, Warsaw"), [Tadeusz Kościuszko Monument](/wiki/Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_Monument,_Warsaw "Tadeusz Kościuszko Monument, Warsaw"), Marie Curie Monument, [Prince Józef Poniatowski Monument](/wiki/Prince_J%C3%B3zef_Antoni_Poniatowski_Monument,_Warsaw "Prince Józef Antoni Poniatowski Monument, Warsaw"), [Nicolaus Copernicus Monument](/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus_Monument,_Warsaw "Nicolaus Copernicus Monument, Warsaw"), [Stefan Starzyński Monument](/wiki/Stefan_Starzy%C5%84ski_Monument "Stefan Starzyński Monument"), [Józef Piłsudski Monument](/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_Monument,_Warsaw "Józef Piłsudski Monument, Warsaw"), [Janusz Korczak Monument](/wiki/Janusz_Korczak_Monument,_Warsaw "Janusz Korczak Monument, Warsaw").^[\[129\]](#cite_note-pomniki-131)^{#cite_ref-pomniki_131-1}  

### Flora and fauna {#Flora_and_fauna}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Flora and fauna")\]

Green space covers almost a quarter of Warsaw's total area.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-warsaw_tour-133)^ These range from small neighborhood parks and green spaces along streets or in courtyards, to tree-lined avenues, large historic parks, nature conservation areas and urban forests at the fringe of the city. There are as many as 82 parks in the city;^[\[132\]](#cite_note-134)^ the oldest ones were once part of representative palaces and include the [Saxon](/wiki/Saxon_Garden "Saxon Garden") and [Krasiński](/wiki/Krasi%C5%84ski_Palace "Krasiński Palace") Gardens, [Łazienki Park](/wiki/%C5%81azienki_Park "Łazienki Park") (Royal Baths Park) and [Wilanów Palace](/wiki/Wilan%C3%B3w_Palace "Wilanów Palace") Parkland.{#cite_ref-134}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Palace_on_the_Water%2C_%C5%81azienki_Park%2C_Warsaw.jpg/220px-Palace_on_the_Water%2C_%C5%81azienki_Park%2C_Warsaw.jpg)](/wiki/File:Palace_on_the_Water,_%C5%81azienki_Park,_Warsaw.jpg) [Łazienki Palace](/wiki/%C5%81azienki_Palace "Łazienki Palace"), also referred to as the *Palace on the Isle*

The Saxon Garden, covering an area of 15.5 ha, formally served as a royal garden to the now nonexistent [Saxon Palace](/wiki/Saxon_Palace "Saxon Palace"). In 1727, it was made into one of the world's first public parks and later remodelled in the forest-like [English style](/wiki/English_Garden "English Garden"). The [Tomb of the Unknown Soldier](/wiki/Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier,_Warsaw "Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, Warsaw") is situated at the east end of the park near the central fountain, on [Piłsudski Square](/wiki/Pi%C5%82sudski_Square "Piłsudski Square"). With its benches, flower carpets and a central pond, the Krasiński Palace Garden was once a notable strolling destination for most Varsovians. The Łazienki Park covers an area of 76 ha and its unique character and history is reflected in the [landscape architecture](/wiki/Landscape_architecture "Landscape architecture") (pavilions, sculptures, bridges, water cascades) and vegetation (domestic and foreign species of trees and shrubs). The presence of [peacocks](/wiki/Indian_peafowl "Indian peafowl"), [pheasants](/wiki/Common_pheasant "Common pheasant") and squirrels at Łazienki attracts tourists and locals. The Wilanów Palace Parkland on the outskirts of Warsaw traces it history to the second half of the 17th century and covers an area of 43 ha. Its [French-styled alleys](/wiki/Garden_%C3%A0_la_fran%C3%A7aise "Garden à la française") corresponds to the ancient, Baroque forms of the palace.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Most_Siekierkowski_Warsaw_2022_aerial.jpg/220px-Most_Siekierkowski_Warsaw_2022_aerial.jpg)](/wiki/File:Most_Siekierkowski_Warsaw_2022_aerial.jpg) A characteristic [riparian zone](/wiki/Riparian_zone "Riparian zone") (riverside forest) in the upper reaches of the Warsaw Vistula, near [Siekierki Bridge](/wiki/Siekierki_Bridge "Siekierki Bridge")

The Botanical Garden and the [University Library](/wiki/Warsaw_University_Library "Warsaw University Library") rooftop garden host an extensive collection of rare domestic and foreign plants, while a [palm house](/wiki/Palm_house "Palm house") in the New Orangery displays plants of subtropics from all over the world.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-135)^ [Mokotów Field](/wiki/Mokot%C3%B3w_Field "Mokotów Field") (once a racetrack), [Ujazdów Park](/wiki/Ujazd%C3%B3w_Park "Ujazdów Park") and [Skaryszewski Park](/wiki/Skaryszewski_Park "Skaryszewski Park") are also located within the city borders. The oldest [park in the Praga](/wiki/Praga_Park "Praga Park") borough was established between 1865 and 1871.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-136)^{#cite_ref-136}

The flora of Warsaw may be considered very rich in species on city standards. This is mainly due to the location of Warsaw within the border region of several big floral regions comprising substantial proportions of close-to-wilderness areas (natural forests, wetlands along the Vistula) as well as [arable land](/wiki/Arable_land "Arable land"), [meadows](/wiki/Meadow "Meadow") and forests. The nearby [Kampinos Nature Reserve](/wiki/Kampinos_Forest "Kampinos Forest") is the last remaining part of the Masovian [Primeval Forest](/wiki/Old-growth_forest "Old-growth forest") and is protected by law.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-137)^ The [Kabaty Woods](/wiki/Kabaty_Woods "Kabaty Woods") are by the southern city border and are visited by the residents of southern boroughs such as [Ursynów](/wiki/Ursyn%C3%B3w "Ursynów"). There are 13 natural reserves in the vicinity and just 15 kilometres (9 miles) from Warsaw, the environment features a perfectly preserved [ecosystem](/wiki/Ecosystem "Ecosystem") with a habitat of animals like the [otter](/wiki/European_otter "European otter"), [beavers](/wiki/European_beaver "European beaver") and hundreds of bird species.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-Kayaking-138)^ There are also several lakes in Warsaw -- mainly the [oxbow lakes](/wiki/Oxbow_lake "Oxbow lake") at [Czerniaków](/wiki/Czerniak%C3%B3w "Czerniaków") and [Kamionek](/wiki/Kamionek "Kamionek").{#cite_ref-Kayaking_138-0}

The [Warsaw Zoo](/wiki/Warsaw_Zoo "Warsaw Zoo") covers an area of 40 hectares (99 acres).^[\[137\]](#cite_note-zoo-139)^ There are about 5,000 animals representing nearly 500 species.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-zoo-139)^ Although officially created in 1928,^[\[137\]](#cite_note-zoo-139)^ it traces back its roots to 17th century private menageries, often open to the public.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-New_Zoo_Revue-140)^^[\[139\]](#cite_note-141)^{#cite_ref-141}

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Demographics")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Warsaw_population_pyramid.svg/220px-Warsaw_population_pyramid.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Warsaw_population_pyramid.svg) Warsaw population pyramid in 2021

[Demographically](/wiki/Demographics "Demographics"), Warsaw was the most diverse city in Poland, with significant numbers of foreign-born residents.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-142)^ In addition to the Polish majority, there was a large and thriving Jewish minority. According to the [Imperial Census of 1897](/wiki/Russian_Empire_Census "Russian Empire Census"), out of the total population of 638,000, Jews constituted 219,000 (equivalent to 34%).^[\[141\]](#cite_note-Zimmerman-143)^ Prior to the Second World War, Warsaw hosted the world's second largest Jewish population after [New York](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") -- approximately 30 percent of the city's total population in the late 1930s.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-ushmm-55)^ In 1933, 833,500 out of 1,178,914 people declared [Polish](/wiki/Polish_language "Polish language") as their mother tongue.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-Brockhaus-144)^ There was also a notable [German community](/wiki/Germans_in_Poland "Germans in Poland").^[\[143\]](#cite_note-145)^ The ethnic composition of contemporary Warsaw is incomparable to the diversity that existed for nearly 300 years.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-ushmm-55)^ Most of the modern-day population growth is based on internal migration and urbanisation. In the [2021 census](/wiki/2021_Polish_census "2021 Polish census"), 98.78% of Warsaw residents identified themselves as [Polish](/wiki/Polish_people "Polish people"), 0.46% as [Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukrainians "Ukrainians"), 0.31% as [Belarusian](/wiki/Belarusians "Belarusians") and 0.21% as [Jewish](/wiki/Jews "Jews").^[\[144\]](#cite_note-146)^{#cite_ref-146}

{#cite_ref-153}

In 1939, approximately 1,300,000 people resided in Warsaw;^[\[152\]](#cite_note-Tihran-154)^ by 1945 the population had dropped to 420,000. During the first years after the war, the population growth rate was high and the city soon began to suffer from the lack of flats and dwellings to house new incomers. The first remedial measure was the enlargement of Warsaw's total area (1951) -- however the city authorities were still forced to introduce limitations; only the spouses and children of permanent residents as well as some persons of public importance (renowned specialists, artists, engineers) were permitted to stay. This negatively affected the image of an average Warsaw citizen, who was perceived as more privileged than those migrating from rural areas, towns or other cities. While all restrictions on residency registration were scrapped in 1990, the negative opinion of Varsovians in some form continues to this day.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-Tihran_154-0}

[Warsaw metropolitan area](/wiki/Warsaw_metropolitan_area "Warsaw metropolitan area") is an example of the development of a strongly polarized region. The capital, along with its immediate surroundings, concentrates over half of the demographic potential of the [Masovian Voivodeship](/wiki/Masovian_Voivodeship "Masovian Voivodeship"), 2/3 of residents with higher education, and 3/4 of larger economic entities employing more than 50 workers. Current demographic development trends are as follows:^[\[153\]](#cite_note-demografia-155)^{#cite_ref-demografia_155-0}

* a clear increase in the number of residents after the [1989 transformations](/wiki/1989_Polish_parliamentary_election "1989 Polish parliamentary election"), from 1.6 to about 2.0 million inhabitants (including unregistered population), mainly due to positive migration balance.
* the highest [migration](/wiki/Human_migration "Human migration") attractiveness in the country for many decades, causing a strong drain of people in the mobile age (18--44 years), including a relatively more frequent influx of women, resulting in high [feminization](/wiki/Feminization "Feminization")
* processes of internal deconcentration of population, consisting of centrifugal migration direction (from central districts to external ones, from external districts to [suburban areas](/wiki/Suburb "Suburb")). Between 1989 and 2017, 213 thousand registered people moved from Warsaw to the suburbs, and in the opposite direction it was only 110 thousand.
* a clear aging of the population: at the end of 2017, people aged 60 and over constituted 27.2% of the registered population, and those aged 70 and over -- 13.5%, while for example in 2002, it was respectively 21.5 and 11.5%

In the coming years, an increase in the city's population is predicted, with migration being the main factor determining the state and structure of Warsaw's population, including mainly internal (national) and external (foreign) influx. Changes in the population are not uniform for the entire Warsaw and in the division into districts, the predicted demographic changes will have a varied course. A decrease in population is forecasted in some central districts ([Praga-Północ](/wiki/Praga-P%C3%B3%C5%82noc "Praga-Północ"), [Śródmieście](/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcie,_Warsaw "Śródmieście, Warsaw")) and an increase in other districts.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-demografia-155)^{#cite_ref-demografia_155-1}  

### Immigrant population {#Immigrant_population}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Immigrant population")\]

In 2019, it was estimated that 40,000 people living in Warsaw were foreign-born. Of those, [Ukrainians](/wiki/Ukrainians_in_Poland "Ukrainians in Poland"), [Vietnamese](/wiki/Vietnamese_people "Vietnamese people"), [Belarusians](/wiki/Belarusians "Belarusians"), and [Russians](/wiki/Russians "Russians") were the most prominent groups.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-156)^ After [Russia's aggression against Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine"), over 1.1 million refugees from Ukraine passed through Warsaw, and at the beginning of March 2022, approximately 40,000 people applied for help every day. According to official data, over 104,000 of Ukrainian citizens who arrived in the first days after the outbreak of the war still reside in the city, including 17,000 young people and children attending urban educational institutions.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-157)^ Due to the [Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine"), the immigrant population has increased significantly to about 340,000.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-158)^{#cite_ref-158}  

### Religion {#Religion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Religion")\]  
See also: [Places of worship in Warsaw](/wiki/Places_of_worship_in_Warsaw "Places of worship in Warsaw")

Religion in Warsaw (2021)^[\[157\]](#cite_note-159)^{#cite_ref-159}

Throughout its existence, Warsaw had been a multi-cultural and multi-religious city.^[\[158\]](#cite_note-160)^ According to the 1901 census, out of 711,988 inhabitants 56.2% were Catholics, 35.7% Jews, 5% Greek Orthodox Christians and 2.8% Protestants.^[\[159\]](#cite_note-161)^ Eight years later, in 1909, there were 281,754 Jews (36.9%), 18,189 Protestants (2.4%) and 2,818 [Mariavites](/wiki/Mariavite_Church "Mariavite Church") (0.4%).^[\[160\]](#cite_note-162)^ This led to construction of hundreds of places of religious worship in all parts of the town. Most of them were destroyed in the aftermath of the [Warsaw Uprising](/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising "Warsaw Uprising") in 1944. After the war, the new communist authorities of Poland discouraged church construction and only a small number were rebuilt.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-163)^{#cite_ref-163}

The [archdiocese of Warsaw](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Warsaw "Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Warsaw") and the [Diocese of Warsaw-Praga](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Warszawa-Praga "Roman Catholic Diocese of Warszawa-Praga") are the two ecclesiastical districts active in the city which serve the large [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic") population of 1.4 million.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-164)^ The [Lutheran Diocese of Warsaw](/wiki/Lutheran_Diocese_of_Warsaw "Lutheran Diocese of Warsaw") is one of six in Poland; its main house of worship is the [Holy Trinity Church](/wiki/Holy_Trinity_Church,_Warsaw "Holy Trinity Church, Warsaw") from 1782, one of Warsaw's most important and historic landmarks. The [Evangelical Reformed Parish](/wiki/Evangelical_Reformed_Parish,_Warsaw "Evangelical Reformed Parish, Warsaw") ([Calvinist](/wiki/Calvinism "Calvinism")) is leading the [Polish Reformed Church](/wiki/Polish_Reformed_Church "Polish Reformed Church"). The main tserkva of the [Orthodox Christians](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church") is Praga's [Cathedral of St. Mary Magdalene](/wiki/Cathedral_of_St._Mary_Magdalene,_Warsaw "Cathedral of St. Mary Magdalene, Warsaw") from 1869. The Jewish Commune of Warsaw (*Gmina Wyznaniowa Żydowska* ) is one of eight in the country; Chief Rabbi of Poland [Michael Schudrich](/wiki/Michael_Schudrich "Michael Schudrich") resides in the city. There are also 3 active [synagogues](/wiki/Synagogue "Synagogue"), one of which is the pre-war [Nożyk Synagogue](/wiki/No%C5%BCyk_Synagogue "Nożyk Synagogue") designated for [Orthodox Jews](/wiki/Orthodox_Judaism "Orthodox Judaism"). An Islamic Cultural Centre in [Ochota](/wiki/Ochota "Ochota") and a small [mosque](/wiki/Mosque "Mosque") in [Wilanów](/wiki/Wilan%C3%B3w "Wilanów") serve the Muslims.{#cite_ref-164}

There are several [Marian shrines](/wiki/Shrines_to_the_Virgin_Mary "Shrines to the Virgin Mary") in the city, including: [sanctuary of the Gracious Mother of God](/wiki/Jesuit_Church,_Warsaw "Jesuit Church, Warsaw") with her image crowned in 1651 in the presence of [King John Casimir](/wiki/John_II_Casimir_Vasa "John II Casimir Vasa"). Another patron of the city is [Blessed Władysław of Gielniów](/wiki/Ladislas_of_Gielni%C3%B3w "Ladislas of Gielniów"), bernardine from the [St. Anne's Church](/wiki/St._Anne%27s_Church,_Warsaw "St. Anne's Church, Warsaw"). The greatest cult is that of [St. Andrew Bobola](/wiki/Andrew_Bobola "Andrew Bobola"), patron of the metropolis of Warsaw, whose [relics](/wiki/Relic "Relic") are in the sanctuary of St. Andrew Bobola in [Mokotów](/wiki/Mokot%C3%B3w "Mokotów").^[\[163\]](#cite_note-165)^{#cite_ref-165}

Government and politics {#Government_and_politics}
--------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Government and politics")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/M%C5%82odziejowski_Palace%2C_Warsaw%2C_Poland%2C_2022%2C_01.jpg/200px-M%C5%82odziejowski_Palace%2C_Warsaw%2C_Poland%2C_2022%2C_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:M%C5%82odziejowski_Palace,_Warsaw,_Poland,_2022,_01.jpg) [Młodziejowski Palace](/wiki/M%C5%82odziejowski_Palace "Młodziejowski Palace"), the seat of the [Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights](/wiki/Office_for_Democratic_Institutions_and_Human_Rights "Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights")

As the capital of Poland, Warsaw is the political centre of the country. Almost all central government institutions are located there, including the [Chancellery of the President](/wiki/Chancellery_of_the_President_of_the_Republic_of_Poland "Chancellery of the President of the Republic of Poland"), both houses of the [Polish Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Poland "Parliament of Poland") (the [lower house](/wiki/Lower_house "Lower house") called [Sejm](/wiki/Sejm "Sejm") and the [upper house](/wiki/Upper_house "Upper house") called [Senate](/wiki/Senate_(Poland) "Senate (Poland)")), the [Chancellery of the Prime Minister](/wiki/Chancellery_of_the_Prime_Minister_of_Poland "Chancellery of the Prime Minister of Poland"), the [Constitutional Tribunal](/wiki/Constitutional_Tribunal_(Poland) "Constitutional Tribunal (Poland)"), the [Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Poland "Supreme Court of Poland"), and the [Supreme Administrative Court](/wiki/Supreme_Administrative_Court_of_Poland "Supreme Administrative Court of Poland"). Warsaw is also host to many major international organizations, including [Frontex](/wiki/Frontex "Frontex") and the [Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights](/wiki/Office_for_Democratic_Institutions_and_Human_Rights "Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights") (the oldest and principal institution of the [Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe](/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe "Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe")).^[\[164\]](#cite_note-166)^^[\[165\]](#cite_note-167)^{#cite_ref-167}

The city is represented in the parliament by 20 [members of Sejm](/wiki/Member_of_Parliament "Member of Parliament") (out of 460) and 4 [senators](/wiki/Senator "Senator") (out of 100). In addition, Warsaw together with its metropolitan area elects 6 [MEPs](/wiki/Member_of_the_European_Parliament "Member of the European Parliament") (Members of the European Parliament) out of 705.  

### Municipal government {#Municipal_government}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Municipal government")\]  
See also: [Warsaw City Council](/wiki/Warsaw_City_Council "Warsaw City Council") and [List of city mayors of Warsaw](/wiki/List_of_city_mayors_of_Warsaw "List of city mayors of Warsaw")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Pa%C5%82ac_Komisji_Rz%C4%85dowej_Przychod%C3%B3w_i_Skarbu_w_Warszawie_2018.jpg/220px-Pa%C5%82ac_Komisji_Rz%C4%85dowej_Przychod%C3%B3w_i_Skarbu_w_Warszawie_2018.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pa%C5%82ac_Komisji_Rz%C4%85dowej_Przychod%C3%B3w_i_Skarbu_w_Warszawie_2018.jpg) [Neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture_in_Poland "Neoclassical architecture in Poland") Commission Palace, the house of the city's government

The first city mayor of Warsaw was Jan Andrzej Menich (1695--1696).^[\[166\]](#cite_note-Petrozolin-168)^ The municipal self-government existed in Warsaw until World War II and was restored in 1990 (during the communist times, the National City Council -- *Miejska Rada Narodowa* -- governed in Warsaw). Since 1990, the structure of city government has been modified several times.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-admin-169)^ Between 1975 and 1990 the Warsaw city mayors simultaneously led the [Warsaw Voivodeship](/wiki/Warsaw_Voivodeship_(1975-1998) "Warsaw Voivodeship (1975-1998)"). In the years 1990--1994, the city mayor of Warsaw was elected by the [city council](/wiki/City_council "City council").^[\[168\]](#cite_note-djordjevic-170)^ Subsequently, a controversial reform was introduced, transforming the city in the years of 1994--1999 into a loose municipal union of several gminas, dominated by one of them, the gmina Centrum encompassing the entire inner city. During this period, the mayor of gmina Centrum who was elected by its council was automatically designated as the city mayor of Warsaw, in spite of representing only a fraction of the population of the city. The city was becoming increasingly unmanageable, especially after the administrative reform of Poland in 1999 which further complicated the local government structure of Warsaw. In 2002, the new *Warsaw Act* of the Polish parliament restored Warsaw as a single urban gmina with the status of a city with powiat rights, led by a unified local government. At the same time, a significant reform was implemented in all Polish municipal governments, introducing direct elections of the wójt/town mayor/city mayor in all Polish gminas.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-djordjevic-170)^ The first city mayor of Warsaw elected according to these rules was [Lech Kaczyński](/wiki/Lech_Kaczy%C5%84ski "Lech Kaczyński"), who however resigned ahead of term when he was elected [President of Polish Republic](/wiki/President_of_Poland "President of Poland") in 2005.{#cite_ref-djordjevic_170-1}

Warsaw has thereafter remained an [urban gmina](/wiki/Urban_gmina "Urban gmina") with the status of a [city with powiat rights](/wiki/City_with_powiat_rights "City with powiat rights").^[\[167\]](#cite_note-admin-169)^ [Legislative power](/wiki/Legislature "Legislature") in Warsaw is vested in a [unicameral](/wiki/Unicameralism "Unicameralism") [Warsaw City Council](/wiki/Warsaw_City_Council "Warsaw City Council") (*Rada Miasta* ), which comprises 60 members.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-admin-169)^ Council members are elected directly every five years (since [2018 election](/wiki/2018_Polish_local_elections "2018 Polish local elections")). Like most legislative bodies, the city council divides itself into committees which have the oversight of various functions of the city government.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-admin-169)^ The city mayor exercises the executive power in the city, being the superior of all unelected municipal- or county-level officials and other employees and supervising all subsidiary entities of the city. The incumbent [city mayor of Warsaw](/wiki/List_of_city_mayors_of_Warsaw "List of city mayors of Warsaw") is [Rafał Trzaskowski](/wiki/Rafa%C5%82_Trzaskowski "Rafał Trzaskowski").{#cite_ref-admin_169-3}

The *Warsaw Act* imposes a mandatory division into 18 auxiliary units called *dzielnica* (district) on the city. In spite of remaining an integral part of the city as an entity, the districts have a degree of autonomy legally guaranteed through a form of an own local self-government exercising some powers devolved by law from the city. They have the duty to assist the city mayor and the City Council in their tasks, such as supervising some municipal companies, city-owned property or schools. Each of the 18 city districts has an own council (*rada dzielnicy* )^[\[167\]](#cite_note-admin-169)^ which elects an executive board (*zarząd dzielnicy* ) headed by a district mayor (*burmistrz dzielnicy*), the latter elected by the council among several candidates nominated by the city mayor of Warsaw among the council's members.{#cite_ref-admin_169-4}

As a result, Warsaw has thereafter continued as an [urban gmina](/wiki/Urban_gmina "Urban gmina") holding status of a [city with powiat rights](/wiki/City_with_powiat_rights "City with powiat rights"), divided into 18 districts (*dzielnica* ),^[\[170\]](#cite_note-172)^ auxiliary municipal units established within the city as an entity as its integral parts, though with some limited powers devolved from the city to their own local self-governments.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-173)^ Each of the districts is customarily subdivided into several neighbourhoods lacking any meaningful legal or administrative powers. The central district of [Śródmieście](/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcie,_Warsaw "Śródmieście, Warsaw") includes the two founding neighbourhoods of the city, called the [Old Town](/wiki/Warsaw_Old_Town "Warsaw Old Town") (*Stare Miasto* ) and the [New Town](/wiki/Warsaw_New_Town "Warsaw New Town") (*Nowe Miasto* ).^[\[172\]](#cite_note-174)^{#cite_ref-174}

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
Main article: [Economy of Poland](/wiki/Economy_of_Poland "Economy of Poland")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Hala_Koszyki_22_pa%C5%BAdziernika_2016.jpg/220px-Hala_Koszyki_22_pa%C5%BAdziernika_2016.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hala_Koszyki_22_pa%C5%BAdziernika_2016.jpg) [Hala Koszyki](/wiki/Hala_Koszyki "Hala Koszyki"), a former [market hall](/wiki/Market_hall "Market hall") from the early 20th century

Warsaw is the leading economic and financial hub of the [Visegrád Group](/wiki/Visegr%C3%A1d_Group "Visegrád Group") and the [Three Seas Initiative](/wiki/Three_Seas_Initiative "Three Seas Initiative"). In 2021, the city's gross metropolitan product (GDP) was estimated at €100 billion, which places Warsaw [20th](/wiki/List_of_EU_metropolitan_areas_by_GDP "List of EU metropolitan areas by GDP") among the [metropolitan areas](/wiki/Metropolitan_area "Metropolitan area") in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") with largest GDP.^[\[176\]](#cite_note-178)^ Warsaw generates almost 1/5 of the [Polish GDP](/wiki/Economy_of_Poland "Economy of Poland") and the country's national income.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-179)^ In 2020, Warsaw was classified as a [global city](/wiki/Global_city "Global city"), because Warsaw is a major global city that links economic regions into the world economy.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-180)^{#cite_ref-180}

Warsaw's city centre ([Śródmieście](/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcie,_Warsaw "Śródmieście, Warsaw")) and commercial [Wola](/wiki/Wola "Wola") district are home not only to many national institutions and government agencies, but also to many domestic and international companies. Warsaw's ever-growing business community has been noticed globally, regionally, and nationally. In 2019 Warsaw was one of the top destinations for foreign investors in Europe.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-181)^{#cite_ref-181}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Varso_Tower_Warsaw_22%28cropped%29.jpg/123px-Varso_Tower_Warsaw_22%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Varso_Tower_Warsaw_22(cropped).jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Warsaw_Spire_2019.jpg/121px-Warsaw_Spire_2019.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warsaw_Spire_2019.jpg)  
[Varso](/wiki/Varso "Varso") and [Warsaw Spire](/wiki/Warsaw_Spire "Warsaw Spire") are the skyscrapers with the largest office space

The average monthly gross salary in the enterprise sector in the last quarter of 2022 amounted to 8,104 [PLN](/wiki/Polish_z%C5%82oty "Polish złoty") and was 404 [PLN](/wiki/Polish_z%C5%82oty "Polish złoty") higher than the average in the [Masovian Voivodeship](/wiki/Masovian_Voivodeship "Masovian Voivodeship") and as much as 1,450 [PLN](/wiki/Polish_z%C5%82oty "Polish złoty") higher than in Poland. The highest gross salary was received by employees working in the information and communication section (11,701.47 [PLN](/wiki/Polish_z%C5%82oty "Polish złoty")). There are 525,475 registered business entities in Warsaw, most of them in the districts of [Śródmieście](/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcie,_Warsaw "Śródmieście, Warsaw"), [Mokotów](/wiki/Mokot%C3%B3w "Mokotów"), [Wola](/wiki/Wola "Wola") and [Praga-Południe](/wiki/Praga-Po%C5%82udnie "Praga-Południe"), 1.1 million people work in the enterprise sector. Warsaw has a well-developed office base, the office space is 6.27 million m2. The largest office buildings are [Varso](/wiki/Varso "Varso") (63,800 m^2^), [Warsaw Spire](/wiki/Warsaw_Spire "Warsaw Spire") (60 000 m^2^), Forest Tower (51,500 m^2^) and P180 (32,000 m^2^), the largest projects under construction are [The Bridge](/wiki/The_Bridge_(Warsaw) "The Bridge (Warsaw)") (47,000 m^2^) and [Skyliner II](/wiki/Skyliner_(Warsaw) "Skyliner (Warsaw)") (38,000 m^2^). The space resources of shopping centers in the Warsaw agglomeration in amount to over 1.7 million m^2^.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-turystyka-182)^{#cite_ref-turystyka_182-0}

In October 2019 Warsaw's unemployment rate was 1.3%, the lowest in the country.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-183)^ Shopping and [consumerism](/wiki/Consumerism "Consumerism") is an important component of Warsaw's economy. The retail streets in Warsaw are [New World Street](/wiki/New_World_Street "New World Street") (*Nowy Świat* ) along with [Krakowskie Przedmieście](/wiki/Krakowskie_Przedmie%C5%9Bcie "Krakowskie Przedmieście"). These streets and their neighboring areas host many luxury stores and popular restaurants. However, most retailers choose to operate in the central shopping centres and [malls](/wiki/Shopping_mall "Shopping mall") such as [Złote Tarasy-Golden Terraces](/wiki/Z%C5%82ote_Tarasy "Złote Tarasy"), [Galeria Mokotów](/wiki/Galeria_Mokot%C3%B3w "Galeria Mokotów") and [Westfield Arkadia](/wiki/Westfield_Arkadia "Westfield Arkadia").^[\[182\]](#cite_note-184)^ [Luxury goods](/wiki/Luxury_goods "Luxury goods") as well as designer labels can be found in the Vitkac Department Store and around [Frascati](/wiki/Frascati,_Warsaw "Frascati, Warsaw").^[\[183\]](#cite_note-185)^{#cite_ref-185}  

### Warsaw Stock Exchange {#Warsaw_Stock_Exchange}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Warsaw Stock Exchange")\]  
Main article: [Warsaw Stock Exchange](/wiki/Warsaw_Stock_Exchange "Warsaw Stock Exchange")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Warsaw8gh.jpg/220px-Warsaw8gh.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warsaw8gh.jpg) The Warsaw Stock Exchange is the largest in Central Europe.

Warsaw's first [stock exchange](/wiki/Stock_exchange "Stock exchange") was established in 1817 and continued trading until World War II. It was re-established in April 1991, following the end of a communist [planned economy](/wiki/Planned_economy "Planned economy") and the reintroduction of a [free-market economy](/wiki/Free_market "Free market").^[\[184\]](#cite_note-stock-186)^ Today, the [Warsaw Stock Exchange](/wiki/Warsaw_Stock_Exchange "Warsaw Stock Exchange") (WSE) is, according to many indicators,^[\[185\]](#cite_note-CEE-187)^ the largest market in the region, with 433 companies listed and total capitalisation of 1 trillion [PLN](/wiki/Polish_z%C5%82oty "Polish złoty") as of 26 November 2020.^[\[186\]](#cite_note-188)^ From 1991 until 2000, the stock exchange was, ironically, located in the building previously used as the headquarters of the communist [Polish United Workers' Party](/wiki/Polish_United_Workers%27_Party "Polish United Workers' Party") (PZPR).^[\[187\]](#cite_note-Tourism-189)^{#cite_ref-Tourism_189-0}  

### Industry {#Industry}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Industry")\]  
[![Powiśle Power Plant](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Elektrownia_Powi%C5%9Ble.jpg/117px-Elektrownia_Powi%C5%9Ble.jpg)](/wiki/File:Elektrownia_Powi%C5%9Ble.jpg)  
[![Praga Koneser Center](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Koneser_Warszawska_Wytw%C3%B3rnia_W%C3%B3dek%2C_Poland%2C_2019%2C_31.jpg/127px-Koneser_Warszawska_Wytw%C3%B3rnia_W%C3%B3dek%2C_Poland%2C_2019%2C_31.jpg)](/wiki/File:Koneser_Warszawska_Wytw%C3%B3rnia_W%C3%B3dek,_Poland,_2019,_31.jpg)  
Examples of revitalized industrial facilities: Powiśle Power Plant (left) and [Praga Koneser Center](/wiki/Praga_Koneser_Center "Praga Koneser Center") within the former [Warsaw Vodka Factory](/wiki/Warsaw_Vodka_Factory_%22Koneser%22 "Warsaw Vodka Factory \"Koneser\"") (right)

The most prominent industries and industrial sectors include high-tech, electrotechnical, chemical, cosmetic, construction, food processing, printing, [metallurgy](/wiki/Metallurgy "Metallurgy"), machinery and clothing. The majority of production plants and facilities are concentrated within the WOP Warsaw Industrial Precinct (*Warszawski Okręg Przemysłowy* ) which is situated around the city's peripheral localities such as [Praga](/wiki/Praga "Praga"), [Pruszków](/wiki/Pruszk%C3%B3w "Pruszków"), [Sochaczew](/wiki/Sochaczew "Sochaczew"), [Piaseczno](/wiki/Piaseczno "Piaseczno"), [Marki](/wiki/Marki "Marki") and [Żyrardów](/wiki/%C5%BByrard%C3%B3w "Żyrardów").^[\[188\]](#cite_note-190)^ Warsaw has developed a particularly strong [retail market](/wiki/Retail "Retail")/sector, representing around 13% of the total retail stock in the country.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-191)^{#cite_ref-191}

Following World War II, the authorities decided that the city will be transformed into a major centre for [heavy industry](/wiki/Heavy_industry "Heavy industry") and manufacturing. As a result, numerous large factories and production facilities were built in and around the city. Among the largest were *Huta Warszawa* [steel works](/wiki/Steel_works "Steel works"), now [arcelor](/wiki/ArcelorMittal "ArcelorMittal")), the [Ursus SA](/wiki/Ursus_SA "Ursus SA"), and the [Fabryka Samochodów Osobowych](/wiki/Fabryka_Samochod%C3%B3w_Osobowych "Fabryka Samochodów Osobowych") (FSO) car factory. The now-defunct FSO, established in 1951, was once Warsaw's most successful corporation. Notable vehicles assembled there over the decades include the [FSO Warszawa](/wiki/FSO_Warszawa "FSO Warszawa"), [FSO Syrena](/wiki/FSO_Syrena "FSO Syrena"), [Polski Fiat 125p](/wiki/Polski_Fiat_125p "Polski Fiat 125p") and the [FSO Polonez](/wiki/FSO_Polonez "FSO Polonez"). In 1995, the factory was purchased by the [South Korean](/wiki/South_Korea "South Korea") car manufacturer [Daewoo](/wiki/Daewoo "Daewoo"), which assembled its models in Warsaw for the European market.  

### Tourism {#Tourism}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Tourism")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Hotel_Europejski_w_Raffles_Warszawie_2019.jpg/218px-Hotel_Europejski_w_Raffles_Warszawie_2019.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hotel_Europejski_w_Raffles_Warszawie_2019.jpg)  
[Hotel Europejski](/wiki/Hotel_Europejski "Hotel Europejski")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Hotel_Polonia_Palace_w_Warszawie_2022.jpg/218px-Hotel_Polonia_Palace_w_Warszawie_2022.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hotel_Polonia_Palace_w_Warszawie_2022.jpg)  
[Hotel Polonia Palace](/wiki/Hotel_Polonia_Palace "Hotel Polonia Palace")

The estimated number of tourist arrivals to Warsaw in 2022 was over 9 million. Most tourists came from the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") (347,000), [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany") (321,000), the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") (206,000) and [France](/wiki/France "France") (145,000). Additionally, Warsaw was visited by 5.8 million one-day tourists, giving a total of over 14.8 million tourists in 2022. The above data does not include [Ukrainian citizens](/wiki/Ukrainians "Ukrainians") who came to Warsaw in connection with the [Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine"). The accommodation base consists of 1,010 hotels offering over 56,000 beds. The estimated contribution of the tourism economy to Warsaw's [GDP](/wiki/GDP "GDP") is 12.9 billion PLN, and the tourism industry employs 87,703 people.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-turystyka-182)^{#cite_ref-turystyka_182-1}

144,220 people used Warsaw Tourist Lines in 2022 - almost 14,000 more than previous year. In the summer, Warsaw residents and tourists could use ferries across the Vistula, a ship to Serock, bus and tram lines operated with historic rolling stock, and a narrow-gauge railway. The most popular attraction among tourists was the [Royal Łazienki Museum](/wiki/Palace_on_the_Isle "Palace on the Isle"), which was visited by 5,265,110 tourists.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-turystyka-182)^{#cite_ref-turystyka_182-2}

Warsaw is an important center for conferences and congresses. The Warsaw Convention Bureau collected information on 9,000 events in 2022, which gathered a total of 1,240,467 participants in Warsaw.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-turystyka-182)^{#cite_ref-turystyka_182-3}  

### Media and film {#Media_and_film}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Media and film")\]  
See also: [List of films set in Warsaw](/wiki/List_of_films_set_in_Warsaw "List of films set in Warsaw")

Warsaw is the media centre of Poland, and the location of the main headquarters of [TVP](/wiki/Telewizja_Polska "Telewizja Polska") and other numerous local and national TV and [radio stations](/wiki/Radio_broadcasting "Radio broadcasting"), such as [Polskie Radio](/wiki/Polskie_Radio "Polskie Radio") (Polish Radio), [TVN](/wiki/TVN_(Poland) "TVN (Poland)"), [Polsat](/wiki/Polsat "Polsat"), [TV4](/wiki/TV4_(Poland) "TV4 (Poland)"), [TV Puls](/wiki/TV_Puls "TV Puls"), [Canal+ Poland](/wiki/Canal%2B_Poland "Canal+ Poland"), [Cyfra+](/wiki/Cyfra%2B "Cyfra+") and [MTV Poland](/wiki/MTV_Poland "MTV Poland").^[\[190\]](#cite_note-broadbandtvnews-192)^ Warsaw also has a sizable movie and television industry. The city houses several movie companies and [studios](/wiki/Movie_studio "Movie studio").{#cite_ref-broadbandtvnews_192-0}

Since May 1661 the first Polish newspaper, the *[Polish Ordinary Mercury](/wiki/Merkuriusz_Polski_Ordynaryjny "Merkuriusz Polski Ordynaryjny")* , was printed in Warsaw. The city is also the printing capital of Poland with a wide variety of domestic and foreign periodicals expressing diverse views, and domestic newspapers are extremely competitive. *[Rzeczpospolita](/wiki/Rzeczpospolita_(newspaper) "Rzeczpospolita (newspaper)")* , *[Gazeta Wyborcza](/wiki/Gazeta_Wyborcza "Gazeta Wyborcza")* and *[Dziennik Polska-Europa-Świat](/wiki/Dziennik_Polska-Europa-%C5%9Awiat "Dziennik Polska-Europa-Świat")* , Poland's large nationwide daily newspapers,^[\[191\]](#cite_note-instytut-193)^ have their headquarters in Warsaw.{#cite_ref-instytut_193-0}

Since World War II, Warsaw has been the most important centre of film production in Poland. Among the movie companies are TOR, Czołówka, Zebra and [Kadr](/wiki/KADR_(studio) "KADR (studio)") which is behind several international movie productions.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-pisf-194)^ The city itself has featured in numerous movies, both Polish and foreign, for example: [*Kanał*](/wiki/Kana%C5%82_(film) "Kanał (film)") and *[Korczak](/wiki/Korczak_(film) "Korczak (film)")* by [Andrzej Wajda](/wiki/Andrzej_Wajda "Andrzej Wajda") and *[The Decalogue](/wiki/The_Decalogue_(film) "The Decalogue (film)")* by [Krzysztof Kieślowski](/wiki/Krzysztof_Kie%C5%9Blowski "Krzysztof Kieślowski"), also including [Oscar](/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award") winner [*The Pianist*](/wiki/The_Pianist_(2002_film) "The Pianist (2002 film)") by [Roman Polański](/wiki/Roman_Polanski "Roman Polanski").^[\[193\]](#cite_note-thepianistmovie-195)^ It is also home to the National Film Archive, which, since 1955, has been collecting and preserving Polish film culture.^[\[194\]](#cite_note-196)^{#cite_ref-196}

Warsaw holds some of the finest institutions of higher education in Poland. It is home to four major universities and over 62 smaller schools of higher education.^[\[195\]](#cite_note-gus-197)^ The overall number of students of all grades of education in Warsaw is almost 500,000 (29.2% of the city population; 2002). The number of university students is over 280,000.^[\[196\]](#cite_note-Studia-198)^ Most of the reputable universities are public, but in recent years there has also been an upsurge in the number of private universities.{#cite_ref-Studia_198-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Brama_Uniwersytetu_Warszawskiego.jpg/220px-Brama_Uniwersytetu_Warszawskiego.jpg)](/wiki/File:Brama_Uniwersytetu_Warszawskiego.jpg) The main gate of the [University of Warsaw](/wiki/University_of_Warsaw "University of Warsaw")

The [University of Warsaw](/wiki/University_of_Warsaw "University of Warsaw") was established in 1816, when the partitions of Poland separated Warsaw from the oldest and most influential Polish academic center, in [Kraków](/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w "Kraków").^[\[197\]](#cite_note-uw_edu-199)^ The university is the largest in the country, and often regarded as one of the most prestigious, with international recognition in mathematics and science.^[\[198\]](#cite_note-200)^^[\[199\]](#cite_note-201)^^[\[200\]](#cite_note-202)^ [Warsaw University of Technology](/wiki/Warsaw_University_of_Technology "Warsaw University of Technology") is the second academic school of technology in the country, and one of the largest in [East-Central Europe](/wiki/East-Central_Europe "East-Central Europe").^[\[201\]](#cite_note-onelab-203)^ Other institutions for higher education include the [Medical University of Warsaw](/wiki/Medical_University_of_Warsaw "Medical University of Warsaw"), the largest medical school in Poland and one of the most prestigious; the [National Defence](/wiki/Defense_(military) "Defense (military)") University, the highest military academic institution in Poland; the [Fryderyk Chopin University of Music](/wiki/Fryderyk_Chopin_University_of_Music "Fryderyk Chopin University of Music"), the oldest and largest music school in Poland and one of the largest in Europe;^[\[202\]](#cite_note-infochopin-204)^ the [Warsaw School of Economics](/wiki/Warsaw_School_of_Economics "Warsaw School of Economics"), the oldest and most renowned economic university in the country;^[\[203\]](#cite_note-sgh_waw-205)^ the [Warsaw University of Life Sciences](/wiki/Warsaw_University_of_Life_Sciences "Warsaw University of Life Sciences"), the largest agricultural university, founded in 1818;^[\[204\]](#cite_note-sggw-206)^ and the [University of Social Sciences and Humanities](/wiki/University_of_Social_Sciences_and_Humanities "University of Social Sciences and Humanities"), the first private secular university in the country.{#cite_ref-sggw_206-0}

Warsaw has numerous libraries, many of which contain vast collections of historic documents. The most important library in terms of historic document collections is the [National Library of Poland](/wiki/National_Library_of_Poland "National Library of Poland"). The library holds 8.2 million volumes in its collection.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-bn_org-207)^ Formed in 1928,^[\[206\]](#cite_note-fyifrance-208)^ it sees itself as a successor to the [Załuski Library](/wiki/Za%C5%82uski_Library "Załuski Library"), the biggest in Poland and one of the first and biggest libraries in the world.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-fyifrance-208)^^[\[207\]](#cite_note-utoronto-209)^{#cite_ref-utoronto_209-0}

Another important library -- the University Library, founded in 1816,^[\[208\]](#cite_note-buw-210)^ is home to over two million items.^[\[209\]](#cite_note-Zbiory-211)^ The building was designed by architects Marek Budzyński and Zbigniew Badowski and opened on 15 December 1999.^[\[210\]](#cite_note-Library-212)^ It is surrounded by green. The University Library garden, designed by Irena Bajerska, was opened on 12 June 2002. It is one of the largest roof gardens in Europe with an area of more than 10,000 m^2^ (110,000 sq ft), and plants covering 5,111 m^2^ (55,010 sq ft).^[\[211\]](#cite_note-garden-213)^ As the university garden it is open to the public every day.^[\[211\]](#cite_note-garden-213)^{#cite_ref-garden_213-1}

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Transport")\]  
Main articles: [Transport in Warsaw](/wiki/Transport_in_Warsaw "Transport in Warsaw") and [Infrastructure in Warsaw](/wiki/Infrastructure_in_Warsaw "Infrastructure in Warsaw")

Warsaw is a considerable transport hub linking [Western](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe"), Central and Eastern Europe. The city has a good [network of buses](/wiki/Bus_transport_in_Warsaw "Bus transport in Warsaw") and a continuously expanding perpendicular [metro](/wiki/Warsaw_metro "Warsaw metro") running north to south and east to west. The [tram system](/wiki/Trams_in_Warsaw "Trams in Warsaw") is one of the biggest in Europe, with a total length of 133 km (83 mi).^[\[212\]](#cite_note-ZTM_2022-214)^ As a result of increased foreign investment, economic growth and EU funding, the city has undertaken the construction of new roads, [flyovers](/wiki/Overpass "Overpass") and bridges.^[\[213\]](#cite_note-Jeziorski-215)^ The supervising body is the City Roads Authority (ZDM -- *Zarząd Dróg Miejskich*).{#cite_ref-Jeziorski_215-0}  

### Public transport {#Public_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Public transport")\]

The first section of the [Warsaw Metro](/wiki/Warsaw_Metro "Warsaw Metro") was opened in 1995 initially with a total of 11 stations.^[\[214\]](#cite_note-metro-216)^ As of 2024, it has 39 stations running a distance of approximately 41 km (25 mi).^[\[215\]](#cite_note-217)^{#cite_ref-217}

Public transport also extends to [light rail](/wiki/Light_rail "Light rail") [Warszawska Kolej Dojazdowa](/wiki/Warszawska_Kolej_Dojazdowa "Warszawska Kolej Dojazdowa") line, urban railway [Szybka Kolej Miejska](/wiki/Szybka_Kolej_Miejska_(Warsaw) "Szybka Kolej Miejska (Warsaw)"), [regional rail](/wiki/Regional_rail "Regional rail") [Koleje Mazowieckie](/wiki/Koleje_Mazowieckie "Koleje Mazowieckie") (Mazovian Railways),^[\[216\]](#cite_note-218)^ and [bicycle sharing systems](/wiki/Bicycle_sharing_system "Bicycle sharing system") ([Veturilo](/wiki/Veturilo "Veturilo")). The buses, trams, urban railway and Metro are managed by the [Public Transport Authority](/wiki/Zarz%C4%85d_Transportu_Miejskiego_w_Warszawie "Zarząd Transportu Miejskiego w Warszawie") and are collectively known as Warsaw Public Transport.{#cite_ref-218}

In the photo, [Poniatowski Bridge](/wiki/Poniatowski_Bridge "Poniatowski Bridge") and [Świętokrzyski Bridge](/wiki/%C5%9Awi%C4%99tokrzyski_Bridge "Świętokrzyski Bridge") in the distance

### Roads {#Roads}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Roads")\]

Warsaw lacks a complete [ring road](/wiki/Ring_road "Ring road") system and most traffic goes directly through the city centre, leading to the eleventh highest level of congestion in Europe.^[\[218\]](#cite_note-220)^ The Warsaw ring road has been planned to consist of four [express roads](/wiki/Expressways_of_Poland "Expressways of Poland"): [S2](/wiki/Expressway_S2_(Poland) "Expressway S2 (Poland)") (south), [S8](/wiki/Expressway_S8_(Poland) "Expressway S8 (Poland)") (north-west) and [S17](/wiki/Expressway_S17_(Poland) "Expressway S17 (Poland)") (east). S8, S2 and a small 3 km section of S17 are open. Additionally, the S2 and S8 have a [concurrency](/wiki/Concurrency_(road) "Concurrency (road)") with the [S7](/wiki/Expressway_S7_(Poland) "Expressway S7 (Poland)") and the S2 has a short concurrency with the S8. A second ring road consisting of the [A50 motorway](/wiki/A50_autostrada_(Poland) "A50 autostrada (Poland)") (south) and [S50 expressway](/wiki/Expressway_S50_(Poland) "Expressway S50 (Poland)") (north) is also planned but it is unknown when construction will start.{#cite_ref-220}

The [A2 motorway](/wiki/A2_autostrada_(Poland) "A2 autostrada (Poland)") opened in June 2012, stretches west from Warsaw and is a direct motorway connection with Łódź, [Poznań](/wiki/Pozna%C5%84 "Poznań") and ultimately with Berlin.  

### Aviation {#Aviation}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Aviation")\]

The city has three [international airports](/wiki/International_airports "International airports"): [Warsaw Chopin Airport](/wiki/Warsaw_Chopin_Airport "Warsaw Chopin Airport"), located just 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) from the city centre, [Warsaw-Radom Airport](/wiki/Warsaw_Radom_Airport "Warsaw Radom Airport"), located just 90 kilometres (56 mi) south of Warsaw, which serves mainly low-cost and charter operations and finally [Warsaw-Modlin Airport](/wiki/Modlin_Airport "Modlin Airport"), located 35 kilometres (22 mi) to the north, opened in July 2012. With around 100 international and domestic flights a day and with 7,440,056 passengers served in 2021,^[\[219\]](#cite_note-221)^ and it has also been called "the most important and largest airport in Central Europe".^[\[220\]](#cite_note-222)^{#cite_ref-222}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Lotnisko_Chopina_w_Warszawie_2018b.jpg/220px-Lotnisko_Chopina_w_Warszawie_2018b.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lotnisko_Chopina_w_Warszawie_2018b.jpg) [Warsaw Chopin Airport](/wiki/Warsaw_Chopin_Airport "Warsaw Chopin Airport")

[Warsaw Chopin Airport](/wiki/Warsaw_Chopin_Airport "Warsaw Chopin Airport") is the [busiest airport](/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Poland "List of the busiest airports in Poland") in Poland a with 21.3 million passengers in 2024 handling approximately 40% of the country's total air passenger traffic. The airport is a central hub for [LOT Polish Airlines](/wiki/LOT_Polish_Airlines "LOT Polish Airlines") as well as a base for [Enter Air](/wiki/Enter_Air "Enter Air") and [Wizz Air](/wiki/Wizz_Air "Wizz Air"). There are 50 air operations performed at the airport per hour. [London](/wiki/London "London"), [Frankfurt](/wiki/Frankfurt "Frankfurt"), [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris"), and [Amsterdam](/wiki/Amsterdam "Amsterdam") are the busiest international connections, while [Kraków](/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w "Kraków"), [Wrocław](/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw "Wrocław"), and [Gdańsk](/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk "Gdańsk") are the most popular domestic ones.^[\[221\]](#cite_note-tur1-223)^ The complex contains 45 passenger gates, 27 of which are equipped with jetways. A rail link has been added to connect the city with the airport in 2012.{#cite_ref-tur1_223-0}  

### Rail {#Rail}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Rail")\]

Long distance and intercity trains are operated by [Polish State Railways](/wiki/Polish_State_Railways "Polish State Railways") (PKP). There are also some suburban bus lines run by private operators.^[\[222\]](#cite_note-224)^ [Bus](/wiki/Bus_transport_in_Warsaw "Bus transport in Warsaw") service covers the entire city, with approximately 256 routes totalling above 3,000 kilometres (1,900 mi), and with some 1,700 vehicles.{#cite_ref-224}

The main railway station is [Warszawa Centralna](/wiki/Warszawa_Centralna_railway_station "Warszawa Centralna railway station") serving both domestic traffic to almost every major city in Poland, and international connections. There are also five other major railway stations and a number of smaller suburban stations.

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Culture")\]  

### Music and theatre {#Music_and_theatre}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Music and theatre")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Warszawa%2C_ul._Senatorska_21%2C_25_20170516_001.jpg/220px-Warszawa%2C_ul._Senatorska_21%2C_25_20170516_001.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warszawa,_ul._Senatorska_21,_25_20170516_001.jpg) The edifice of the [Grand Theatre](/wiki/Grand_Theatre,_Warsaw "Grand Theatre, Warsaw") in Warsaw. It is one of the largest theatres in Europe, featuring one of the biggest stages in the world.

Thanks to numerous musical venues, including the [*Teatr Wielki*, the Polish National Opera](/wiki/Great_Theatre,_Warsaw "Great Theatre, Warsaw"), the [Chamber Opera](/wiki/Chamber_opera "Chamber opera"), the [National Philharmonic Hall](/wiki/Warsaw_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Warsaw Philharmonic Orchestra") and the [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre,_Warsaw "National Theatre, Warsaw"), as well as the Roma and Buffo music theatres and the [Congress Hall](/wiki/Congress_Hall_(Warsaw) "Congress Hall (Warsaw)") in the [Palace of Culture and Science](/wiki/Palace_of_Culture_and_Science,_Warsaw "Palace of Culture and Science, Warsaw"), Warsaw hosts many events and festivals. Among the events worth particular attention are: the [International Frédéric Chopin Piano Competition](/wiki/International_Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Chopin_Piano_Competition "International Frédéric Chopin Piano Competition"), the International Contemporary Music Festival [Warsaw Autumn](/wiki/Warsaw_Autumn "Warsaw Autumn"), the Jazz Jamboree, Warsaw Summer Jazz Days, the International [Stanisław Moniuszko](/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Moniuszko "Stanisław Moniuszko") Vocal Competition, the Mozart Festival, and the Festival of Old Music.^[\[223\]](#cite_note-salter-225)^{#cite_ref-salter_225-0}

Warsaw is also considered one of the European hubs of underground electronic music with a very attractive house and techno music scene.^[\[224\]](#cite_note-226)^{#cite_ref-226}

Warsaw is home to over 30 major theatres spread throughout the city, including the [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre,_Warsaw "National Theatre, Warsaw") (founded in 1765) and the [Grand Theatre](/wiki/Grand_Theatre,_Warsaw "Grand Theatre, Warsaw") (established 1778).^[\[225\]](#cite_note-teatrwielki1-227)^{#cite_ref-teatrwielki1_227-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Filharmonia_Narodowa_wej%C5%9Bcie_g%C5%82%C3%B3wne_2020.jpg/220px-Filharmonia_Narodowa_wej%C5%9Bcie_g%C5%82%C3%B3wne_2020.jpg)](/wiki/File:Filharmonia_Narodowa_wej%C5%9Bcie_g%C5%82%C3%B3wne_2020.jpg) [Warsaw Philharmonic](/wiki/Warsaw_Philharmonic "Warsaw Philharmonic") is a venue for the [International Chopin Piano Competition](/wiki/International_Chopin_Piano_Competition "International Chopin Piano Competition")

Warsaw also attracts many young and off-stream directors and performers who add to the city's theatrical culture. Their productions may be viewed mostly in smaller theatres and *Houses of Culture* (*Domy Kultury* ), mostly outside *[Śródmieście](/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C3%B3dmie%C5%9Bcie,_Warsaw "Śródmieście, Warsaw")* (Central Warsaw). Warsaw hosts the International Theatrical Meetings.

From 1833 to the outbreak of World War II, Plac Teatralny *([Theatre Square](/wiki/Theatre_Square_(Warsaw) "Theatre Square (Warsaw)"))* was the country's cultural hub and home to the various theatres.^[\[226\]](#cite_note-teatrwielki-228)^ Plac Teatralny and its environs was the venue for numerous parades, celebrations of state holidays, carnival balls and concerts.{#cite_ref-teatrwielki_228-0}

The main building housed the [Great Theatre](/wiki/Great_Theatre,_Warsaw "Great Theatre, Warsaw") from 1833 to 1834, the Rozmaitości Theatre from 1836 to 1924 and then the National Theatre, the Reduta Theatre from 1919 to 1924, and from 1928 to 1939 -- the Nowy Theatre, which staged productions of contemporary poetical drama, including those directed by [Leon Schiller](/wiki/Leon_Schiller "Leon Schiller").^[\[226\]](#cite_note-teatrwielki-228)^{#cite_ref-teatrwielki_228-1}

Nearby, in Ogród Saski (the [Saxon Garden](/wiki/Saxon_Garden "Saxon Garden")), the Summer Theatre was in operation from 1870 to 1939,^[\[227\]](#cite_note-Letni-229)^ and in the [inter-war period](/wiki/Interwar_period "Interwar period"), the theatre complex also included Momus, Warsaw's first literary cabaret, and [Leon Schiller](/wiki/Leon_Schiller "Leon Schiller")'s musical theatre Melodram. The [Wojciech Bogusławski](/wiki/Wojciech_Bogus%C5%82awski "Wojciech Bogusławski") Theatre (1922--26) was the best example of "Polish monumental theatre". From the mid-1930s, the Great Theatre building housed the Upati Institute of Dramatic Arts -- the first state-run academy of dramatic art, with an acting department and a stage directing department.^[\[226\]](#cite_note-teatrwielki-228)^{#cite_ref-teatrwielki_228-2}  

### Museums and art galleries {#Museums_and_art_galleries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Museums and art galleries")\]

|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Museums in Warsaw * [National Museum](/wiki/National_Museum,_Warsaw "National Museum, Warsaw") * [Zachęta](/wiki/Zach%C4%99ta "Zachęta") National Gallery of Art * [Royal Castle](/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw "Royal Castle, Warsaw") * [Warsaw Uprising Museum](/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising_Museum "Warsaw Uprising Museum") * [Copernicus Science Centre](/wiki/Copernicus_Science_Centre "Copernicus Science Centre") * [Museum of Evolution of Polish Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Museum_of_Evolution_of_Polish_Academy_of_Sciences "Museum of Evolution of Polish Academy of Sciences") * [Museum of the Earth of the Polish Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Museum_of_the_Earth_of_the_Polish_Academy_of_Sciences "Museum of the Earth of the Polish Academy of Sciences") * [Centre for Contemporary Art](/wiki/Ujazd%C3%B3w_Castle#Centre_for_Contemporary_Art "Ujazdów Castle") * [Museum of Modern Art](/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art,_Warsaw "Museum of Modern Art, Warsaw") * [Museum of the Polish Army](/wiki/Polish_Army_Museum "Polish Army Museum") * [Fryderyk Chopin Museum](/wiki/Fryderyk_Chopin_Museum "Fryderyk Chopin Museum") * [Museum of Warsaw](/wiki/Museum_of_Warsaw "Museum of Warsaw") * [Museum of Polish History](/wiki/Museum_of_Polish_History "Museum of Polish History") * [Museum of Independence](/wiki/Museum_of_Independence "Museum of Independence") * [Museum of the History of the Polish Jews](/wiki/Museum_of_the_History_of_the_Polish_Jews "Museum of the History of the Polish Jews") * [Museum of Sport and Tourism](/wiki/Museum_of_Sport_and_Tourism "Museum of Sport and Tourism") * [Legia Warsaw Museum](/wiki/Legia_Warsaw_Museum "Legia Warsaw Museum") * [Museum of Communism](/wiki/Museum_of_Communism,_Poland "Museum of Communism, Poland") * [Museum of Caricature](/wiki/Museum_of_Caricature,_Warsaw "Museum of Caricature, Warsaw") * [Maria Skłodowska-Curie Museum](/wiki/Maria_Sk%C5%82odowska-Curie_Museum "Maria Skłodowska-Curie Museum") |

There are over 60 museums and galleries in Warsaw which are accessible to the public.^[\[228\]](#cite_note-230)^ Among the positions are the world's first [Museum of Posters](/wiki/Poster_Museum,_Wilan%C3%B3w "Poster Museum, Wilanów") boasting one of the largest collections of art [posters](/wiki/Poster "Poster") in the world,^[\[229\]](#cite_note-postermuseum-231)^ and the [Museum of the History of Polish Jews](/wiki/POLIN_Museum_of_the_History_of_Polish_Jews "POLIN Museum of the History of Polish Jews"). Among the most prestigious ones are the [National Museum](/wiki/National_Museum,_Warsaw "National Museum, Warsaw") with a collection of works whose origin ranges in time from antiquity until the present epoch as well as one of the best collections of paintings in the country including some paintings from Adolf Hitler's private collection,^[\[230\]](#cite_note-Schwarz-232)^ and the [Museum of the Polish Army](/wiki/Polish_Army_Museum "Polish Army Museum") whose set portrays the history of arms.{#cite_ref-Schwarz_232-0}

The collections of [Łazienki](/wiki/%C5%81azienki_Palace "Łazienki Palace") and [Wilanów](/wiki/Wilan%C3%B3w_Palace "Wilanów Palace") palaces focus on the paintings of the "old masters", as do those of the Royal Castle which displays the [Lanckoroński Collection](/wiki/Palais_Lanckoro%C5%84ski#Lanckoroński_Collection "Palais Lanckoroński") including two paintings by Rembrandt.^[\[231\]](#cite_note-Wetering-233)^ The Palace in [Natolin](/wiki/Natolin_Palace_and_Park_Complex "Natolin Palace and Park Complex"), a former rural residence of Duke [Czartoryski](/wiki/Czartoryski_family "Czartoryski family"), is another venue with its interiors and park accessible to tourists.{#cite_ref-Wetering_233-0}

The famous [Copernicus Science Centre](/wiki/Copernicus_Science_Centre "Copernicus Science Centre") is an interactive science museum containing over 450 exhibits, enabling visitors to carry out experiments and discover the laws of science for themselves. Warsaw does not have a natural history museum. Yet, it hosts small museums of [Evolution](/wiki/Museum_of_Evolution_of_Polish_Academy_of_Sciences "Museum of Evolution of Polish Academy of Sciences") and [the Earth](/wiki/Museum_of_the_Earth_of_the_Polish_Academy_of_Sciences "Museum of the Earth of the Polish Academy of Sciences"), which play a similar role.

Holding Poland's largest private collection of art, the [Carroll Porczyński Collection Museum](/wiki/Museum_of_John_Paul_II_Collection "Museum of John Paul II Collection")^[\[232\]](#cite_note-234)^ displays works from such varied artists as [Paris Bordone](/wiki/Paris_Bordone "Paris Bordone"), [Cornelis van Haarlem](/wiki/Cornelis_van_Haarlem "Cornelis van Haarlem"), [José de Ribera](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_de_Ribera "José de Ribera"), [William-Adolphe Bouguereau](/wiki/William-Adolphe_Bouguereau "William-Adolphe Bouguereau"), [Pierre-Auguste Renoir](/wiki/Pierre-Auguste_Renoir "Pierre-Auguste Renoir"), and [Vincent van Gogh](/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh "Vincent van Gogh")^[\[233\]](#cite_note-muzeummalarstwa-235)^ along with some copies of masterpieces of European painting.{#cite_ref-muzeummalarstwa_235-0}

A fine tribute to the fall of Warsaw and [history of Poland](/wiki/History_of_Poland "History of Poland") can be found in the [Warsaw Uprising Museum](/wiki/Warsaw_Rising_Museum "Warsaw Rising Museum") and in the [Katyń Museum](/wiki/Katy%C5%84_Museum "Katyń Museum") which preserves the memory of that crime.^[\[234\]](#cite_note-Baker-236)^ The Warsaw Uprising Museum also operates a rare preserved and operating historic stereoscopic theatre, the [Warsaw Fotoplastikon](/wiki/Warsaw_Fotoplastikon "Warsaw Fotoplastikon"). The [Museum of Independence](/wiki/Museum_of_Independence "Museum of Independence") preserves patriotic and political objects connected with Poland's struggles for independence. Dating back to 1936 the [Warsaw Historical Museum](/wiki/Museum_of_Warsaw "Museum of Warsaw") contains 60 rooms which host a permanent exhibition of the history of Warsaw from its origins until today.{#cite_ref-Baker_236-0}

The 17th century Royal [Ujazdów Castle](/wiki/Ujazd%C3%B3w_Castle "Ujazdów Castle") houses the Centre for Contemporary Art, with some permanent and temporary exhibitions, concerts, shows and creative workshops. The Centre realizes about 500 projects a year. The [Zachęta](/wiki/Zach%C4%99ta "Zachęta") National Gallery of Art, the oldest exhibition site in Warsaw, with a tradition stretching back to the mid-19th century organises exhibitions of [modern art](/wiki/Modern_art "Modern art") by Polish and [International Artists](/wiki/International_Artists "International Artists") and promotes art in many other ways. Since 2011, [Warsaw Gallery Weekend](/wiki/Warsaw_Gallery_Weekend "Warsaw Gallery Weekend") is held on the last weekend of September.

28 September 2023 the opening of the new building of the [Museum of Polish History](/wiki/Museum_of_Polish_History "Museum of Polish History") located at the [Warsaw Citadel](/wiki/Warsaw_Citadel "Warsaw Citadel") took place.

The city also possesses some oddities such as the [Neon Museum](/wiki/Neon_Museum,_Warsaw "Neon Museum, Warsaw"), the [Museum of Caricature](/wiki/Museum_of_Caricature,_Warsaw "Museum of Caricature, Warsaw"),^[\[235\]](#cite_note-Exhibitions-237)^ the [Museum of John Paul II and Primate Wyszyński](/wiki/Museum_of_John_Paul_II_and_Primate_Wyszy%C5%84ski "Museum of John Paul II and Primate Wyszyński"), the [Legia Warsaw Museum](/wiki/Legia_Warsaw_Museum "Legia Warsaw Museum"), and a Motorisation Museum in [Otrębusy](/wiki/Otr%C4%99busy "Otrębusy").^[\[236\]](#cite_note-motoryzacji-238)^{#cite_ref-motoryzacji_238-0}
