### Cuisine and food {#Cuisine_and_food}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Cuisine and food")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Wuzetka_edit.JPG/220px-Wuzetka_edit.JPG)](/wiki/File:Wuzetka_edit.JPG) [Wuzetka](/wiki/Wuzetka "Wuzetka") chocolate cake originated in Warsaw and is an icon of the city.

Warsaw's culinary tradition was shaped by its once multicultural population; its cuisine is distinct from that of other cities and towns in Poland.^[\[237\]](#cite_note-239)^^[\[238\]](#cite_note-auto2-240)^ Strong [Jewish](/wiki/Jewish_cuisine "Jewish cuisine") and [French](/wiki/French_cuisine "French cuisine") influences were cultivated over the years, in particular [herring](/wiki/Herring "Herring"), [consommé](/wiki/Consomm%C3%A9 "Consommé"), [bagels](/wiki/Bagels "Bagels"), [aspic](/wiki/Aspic "Aspic") and French [meringue](/wiki/Meringue "Meringue")-based pastries or cakes.^[\[239\]](#cite_note-auto1-241)^ Traditional Varsovian food is hearty and includes a [tripe soup](/wiki/Tripe_soup "Tripe soup") for entrée, a [pyza](/wiki/Pyzy_(dish) "Pyzy (dish)") dumpling for main and the iconic [wuzetka](/wiki/Wuzetka "Wuzetka") (voo-zetka) chocolate cream pie for dessert.^[\[239\]](#cite_note-auto1-241)^^[\[240\]](#cite_note-242)^ [Crayfish](/wiki/Crayfish "Crayfish") and [fish in gelatin](/wiki/Aspic "Aspic") were the classical dishes in Warsaw's restaurants throughout the 1920s and the 1930s.^[\[238\]](#cite_note-auto2-240)^{#cite_ref-auto2_240-1}

Much like [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") or [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), Warsaw once possessed a prominent [café culture](/wiki/Parisian_caf%C3%A9 "Parisian café") which dated back to the early 18th century, and the city's cafeterias were a place for socializing.^[\[241\]](#cite_note-243)^ The historic [Wedel](/wiki/E._Wedel "E. Wedel") Chocolate Lounge on Szpitalna Street remains one of the most renowned spots for social gatherings. Cafeterias, confectioneries and patisseries such as [Caffè Nero](/wiki/Caff%C3%A8_Nero "Caffè Nero"), [Costa Coffee](/wiki/Costa_Coffee "Costa Coffee") and [Starbucks](/wiki/Starbucks "Starbucks") are predominantly found along the Royal Route on [New World Street](/wiki/New_World_Street "New World Street"). Thousands of Warsaw's residents also flock annually to the pastry workshops (*pączkarnia* ) to buy [pączki](/wiki/P%C4%85czki "Pączki") doughnuts on [Fat Thursday](/wiki/Fat_Thursday "Fat Thursday").^[\[242\]](#cite_note-244)^{#cite_ref-244}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Staro%C5%9Bwiecki_Sklep_Wedla_Szpitalna_8_Warszawa.JPG/220px-Staro%C5%9Bwiecki_Sklep_Wedla_Szpitalna_8_Warszawa.JPG)](/wiki/File:Staro%C5%9Bwiecki_Sklep_Wedla_Szpitalna_8_Warszawa.JPG) Interior of the [Wedel](/wiki/E._Wedel "E. Wedel") Chocolate Lounge on Szpitalna Street

Restaurants offering authentic [Polish cuisine](/wiki/Polish_cuisine "Polish cuisine") are concentrated around the Old Town district. Various [spit cakes](/wiki/Spit_cake "Spit cake") of [Czech](/wiki/Czech_Republic "Czech Republic") or [Hungarian](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary") origin ([kürtőskalács](/wiki/K%C3%BCrt%C5%91skal%C3%A1cs "Kürtőskalács") and [trdelník](/wiki/Trdeln%C3%ADk "Trdelník")) are also sold primarily in the Old Town.^[\[243\]](#cite_note-245)^ Hala Koszyki is a popular meeting place in Warsaw noted for its food hall.^[\[244\]](#cite_note-246)^{#cite_ref-246}

In the 20th century, Warsaw was famed for its state-owned [milk bars](/wiki/Milk_bar "Milk bar") (*[bar mleczny](/wiki/Bar_mleczny "Bar mleczny")* ) which offered cheap [fast food](/wiki/Fast_food "Fast food") in the form of home dinners. Examples of dishes popularized by these canteens include [tomato soup](/wiki/Tomato_soup "Tomato soup"), [schnitzels](/wiki/Schnitzel "Schnitzel"), [frikadeller](/wiki/Frikadeller "Frikadeller"), [mizeria salad](/wiki/Mizeria "Mizeria") and many others. Contemporary fast food giants like [McDonald's](/wiki/McDonald%27s "McDonald's"), [KFC](/wiki/KFC "KFC"), [Subway](/wiki/Subway_(restaurant) "Subway (restaurant)") and [Burger King](/wiki/Burger_King "Burger King") are the successors to milk bars, though some reemerged in recent years due to widespread [nostalgia](/wiki/Nostalgia "Nostalgia").^[\[245\]](#cite_note-247)^{#cite_ref-247}

Gourmet and [haute cuisine](/wiki/Haute_cuisine "Haute cuisine") establishments are situated in the vicinity of the downtown area or in the [Frascati](/wiki/Frascati,_Warsaw "Frascati, Warsaw") neighbourhood. Thirteen Varsovian restaurants were appreciated by the [Michelin Guide](/wiki/Michelin_Guide "Michelin Guide"), with two receiving a michelin star in 2019.^[\[246\]](#cite_note-248)^^[\[247\]](#cite_note-249)^{#cite_ref-249}

In 2021, [National Geographic](/wiki/National_Geographic "National Geographic") named Warsaw one of the top cities for [vegans](/wiki/Veganism "Veganism") in Europe. Śródmieście Południowe (Southern Downtown) and its "hipster food culture" was singled out as the epicenter.^[\[248\]](#cite_note-250)^{#cite_ref-250}  

### Events {#Events}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Events")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Three_Kings.jpg/220px-Three_Kings.jpg)](/wiki/File:Three_Kings.jpg) Annual procession of the Three Wise Men (Epiphany) at Warsaw's Castle Square

Several commemorative events take place every year, notably the [Orange Warsaw Festival](/wiki/Orange_Warsaw_Festival "Orange Warsaw Festival") featuring music concerts. One of the more popular events is the [procession](/wiki/Procession "Procession") of the [Three Wise Men](/wiki/Biblical_Magi "Biblical Magi") (in Polish known as the Three Kings) on [Epiphany](/wiki/Epiphany_(holiday) "Epiphany (holiday)"), shortly after the [New Year](/wiki/New_Year "New Year"). Paper crowns are usually worn by spectators throughout the day. The event, which runs along the Royal Route, is attended by Warsaw's highest officials and by the Polish president who resides nearby.^[\[249\]](#cite_note-251)^^[\[250\]](#cite_note-252)^{#cite_ref-252}

Gatherings of thousands of people on the banks of the Vistula on Midsummer's Night for a festival called [Wianki](/wiki/Wianki "Wianki") (Polish for *Wreaths* ) have also become a tradition and a yearly event in the programme of cultural events in Warsaw.^[\[251\]](#cite_note-sobotka-253)^^[\[252\]](#cite_note-wreath-254)^ The festival traces its roots to a peaceful [pagan](/wiki/Paganism "Paganism") ritual where maidens would float their [wreaths](/wiki/Wreath "Wreath") of herbs on the water to predict when they would be married, and to whom.^[\[251\]](#cite_note-sobotka-253)^ By the 19th century this tradition had become a festive event, and it continues today.^[\[251\]](#cite_note-sobotka-253)^ The city council organize concerts and other events.^[\[252\]](#cite_note-wreath-254)^ Each Midsummer's Eve, apart from the official floating of wreaths, jumping over fires, and looking for the [fern flower](/wiki/Fern_flower "Fern flower"), there are musical performances, dignitaries' speeches, fairs and fireworks by the river bank.^[\[252\]](#cite_note-wreath-254)^{#cite_ref-wreath_254-2}

Warsaw Multimedia Fountain Park is located in an enchanting place, near the Old Town and the Vistula. The 'Water -- Light -- Sound' multimedia shows take place each Friday and Saturday from May until September at 9.30 pm (May and -- 9 October pm). On other weekdays, the shows do not include lasers and sound.

The [Warsaw Film festival](/wiki/Warsaw_Film_Festival "Warsaw Film Festival"), an annual festival that takes place every October.^[\[253\]](#cite_note-wff-255)^ Films are usually screened in their original language with Polish subtitles and participating cinemas include Kinoteka (Palace of Science and Culture), [Multikino](/wiki/Multikino "Multikino") at [Golden Terraces](/wiki/Z%C5%82ote_Tarasy "Złote Tarasy") and Kultura. Over 100 films are shown throughout the festival, and awards are given to the best and most popular films.^[\[253\]](#cite_note-wff-255)^{#cite_ref-wff_255-1}  

### Warsaw Mermaid {#Warsaw_Mermaid}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Warsaw Mermaid")\]  
Main article: [Coat of arms of Warsaw](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Warsaw "Coat of arms of Warsaw")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Warsaw_Sirene_1659.PNG/170px-Warsaw_Sirene_1659.PNG)](/wiki/File:Warsaw_Sirene_1659.PNG) The 1659 [coat of arms of Old Warsaw](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Warsaw "Coat of arms of Warsaw") on the cover of one of Warsaw's accounting books

The mermaid (*syrenka* ) is Warsaw's symbol^[\[254\]](#cite_note-ucl-256)^ and can be found on statues throughout the city and on [the city's coat of arms](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Warsaw "Coat of arms of Warsaw"). This imagery has been in use since at least the mid-14th century.^[\[255\]](#cite_note-Mermaid-257)^ The oldest existing armed seal of Warsaw is from the year 1390, consisting of a round seal bordered with the Latin inscription *Sigilium Civitatis Varsoviensis* (Seal of the city of Warsaw).^[\[256\]](#cite_note-herb-258)^ City records as far back as 1609 document the use of a crude form of a [sea monster](/wiki/Sea_monster "Sea monster") with a female upper body and holding a sword in its claws.^[\[257\]](#cite_note-Bratosiewicz-259)^ In 1653 the poet Zygmunt Laukowski asks the question:{#cite_ref-Bratosiewicz_259-0}
> Warsaw of strong walls; why was the emblem Mermaid with sharp sword, given you by the kings?  
> --- Zygmunt Laukowski^[\[258\]](#cite_note-260)^
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Syrenka_Warszawska.jpg/170px-Syrenka_Warszawska.jpg)](/wiki/File:Syrenka_Warszawska.jpg) 1855 bronze sculpture of *The Warsaw Mermaid* in the [Old Town Market Place](/wiki/Old_Town_Market_Place,_Warsaw "Old Town Market Place, Warsaw")

The Mermaid Statue stands in the very centre of Old Town Square, surrounded by a fountain. Due to vandalism, the original statue had been moved to the grounds of the Museum of Warsaw -- the statue in the square is a copy. This is not the only mermaid in Warsaw. Another is located on the bank of the Vistula River near Świętokrzyski Bridge and another on Karowa Street.

The origin of the legendary figure is not fully known. The best-known legend, by Artur Oppman, is that long ago two of [Triton](/wiki/Triton_(mythology) "Triton (mythology)")'s daughters set out on a journey through the depths of the oceans and seas. One of them decided to stay on the coast of Denmark and can be seen sitting at the entrance to the port of [Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen "Copenhagen"). The second mermaid reached the mouth of the [Vistula](/wiki/Vistula "Vistula") River and plunged into its waters. She stopped to rest on a sandy beach by the village of Warszowa, where fishermen came to admire her beauty and listen to her beautiful voice. A greedy merchant also heard her songs; he followed the fishermen and captured the mermaid.^[\[259\]](#cite_note-legend-261)^{#cite_ref-legend_261-0}

Another legend says that a mermaid once swam to Warsaw from the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea") for the love of the Griffin, the ancient defender of the city, who was killed in a struggle against the [Swedish invasions](/wiki/Deluge_(history) "Deluge (history)") of the 17th century. The mermaid, wishing to avenge his death, took the position of defender of Warsaw, becoming the symbol of the city.^[\[259\]](#cite_note-legend-261)^{#cite_ref-legend_261-1}

Every member of the [Queen's Royal Hussars](/wiki/Queen%27s_Royal_Hussars "Queen's Royal Hussars") of the UK's light [cavalry](/wiki/Cavalry "Cavalry") wears the *Maid of Warsaw* , the crest of the City of Warsaw, on the left sleeve of his No. 2 (Service) Dress.^[\[260\]](#cite_note-qohmuseum-262)^ Members of [651 Squadron Army Air Corps](/wiki/No._651_Squadron_RAF "No. 651 Squadron RAF") of the United Kingdom also wear the *Maid of Warsaw* on the left sleeve of their No. 2 (Service) Dress.^[\[261\]](#cite_note-RAF-263)^{#cite_ref-RAF_263-0}  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Sports")\]  
Main article: [Sport in Warsaw](/wiki/Sport_in_Warsaw "Sport in Warsaw")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Warsaw_National_Stadium_before_Germany_-_Italy_%286%29.jpg/220px-Warsaw_National_Stadium_before_Germany_-_Italy_%286%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warsaw_National_Stadium_before_Germany_-_Italy_(6).jpg) The Interior of the National Stadium before the [UEFA Euro 2012](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012 "UEFA Euro 2012") semi-final match between [Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football team") and [Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football team") on 28 June 2012

On 9 April 2008, the Mayor of Warsaw, [Hanna Gronkiewicz-Waltz](/wiki/Hanna_Gronkiewicz-Waltz "Hanna Gronkiewicz-Waltz"), obtained from the mayor of [Stuttgart](/wiki/Stuttgart "Stuttgart") [Wolfgang Schuster](/wiki/Wolfgang_Schuster "Wolfgang Schuster") a challenge award -- a [commemorative plaque](/wiki/Commemorative_plaque "Commemorative plaque") awarded to Warsaw as the European capital of Sport in 2008.^[\[262\]](#cite_note-264)^{#cite_ref-264}

The [Kazimierz Górski National Stadium](/wiki/Kazimierz_G%C3%B3rski_National_Stadium "Kazimierz Górski National Stadium"), a 58,580-seat-capacity football (soccer) stadium, replaced Warsaw's recently demolished [10th-Anniversary Stadium](/wiki/10th-Anniversary_Stadium "10th-Anniversary Stadium").^[\[263\]](#cite_note-265)^ The National Stadium hosted the opening match, two group matches, a quarter-final, and a semi-final of [UEFA Euro 2012](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012 "UEFA Euro 2012").^[\[264\]](#cite_note-266)^{#cite_ref-266}

There are many sports centres in the city as well. Most of these facilities are swimming pools and sports halls, many of them built by the municipality in the past several years. The main indoor venue is [Hala Torwar](/wiki/Torwar_Hall "Torwar Hall"), used for a variety of indoor sports (it was a venue for the [2009 EuroBasket](/wiki/2009_EuroBasket "2009 EuroBasket")^[\[265\]](#cite_note-267)^ but it is also used as an indoor skating rink). There is also an open-air skating rink (Stegny) and a horse racetrack (Służewiec).{#cite_ref-267}

The best of the city's swimming centres is at Wodny Park Warszawianka, 4 km (2 mi) south of the centre at Merliniego Street, where there's an Olympic-sized pool as well as water slides and children's areas.^[\[266\]](#cite_note-268)^{#cite_ref-268}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Warsaw_Polish_Army_Stadium_6.jpg/220px-Warsaw_Polish_Army_Stadium_6.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warsaw_Polish_Army_Stadium_6.jpg) The Polish Army Stadium, the home ground of [Legia Warsaw](/wiki/Legia_Warsaw "Legia Warsaw") football club

Among the Varsovian football teams, the most recognisable is [Legia Warsaw](/wiki/Legia_Warsaw "Legia Warsaw") -- the army club with a nationwide following play at the [Polish Army Stadium](/wiki/Polish_Army_Stadium "Polish Army Stadium"), just southeast of the centre at [Łazienkowska Street](/wiki/%C5%81azienkowska_Street "Łazienkowska Street"). Established in 1916, they have won the [country's championship](/wiki/Ekstraklasa "Ekstraklasa") fifteen times (most recently in 2021) and won the [Polish Cup](/wiki/Polish_Cup "Polish Cup") nineteen times. In the [1995--96 UEFA Champions League](/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_UEFA_Champions_League "1995–96 UEFA Champions League") season, they reached the quarter-finals, where they lost to Greek club [Panathinaikos](/wiki/Panathinaikos_F.C. "Panathinaikos F.C.").

Their local rivals, [Polonia Warsaw](/wiki/Polonia_Warsaw "Polonia Warsaw"), have significantly fewer supporters, yet they managed to win the country's championship two times (in 1946 and 2000) and won the cup twice as well. Polonia's home venue is located at Konwiktorska Street, a ten-minute walk north from the [Old Town](/wiki/Warsaw_Old_Town "Warsaw Old Town"). Polonia was relegated from the country's top flight in 2013 because of their disastrous financial situation. They are now playing in the first league (2nd tier in Poland).

[Legia Warsaw's basketball team](/wiki/Legia_Warszawa_(basketball) "Legia Warszawa (basketball)") was one of the country's best teams in 50s and 60s. They are now participating in [PLK](/wiki/Polish_Basketball_League "Polish Basketball League"), the highest-tier level of the Polish basketball.  

Famous people {#Famous_people}
------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Warsaw&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Famous people")\]  
Further information: [List of people from Warsaw](/wiki/List_of_people_from_Warsaw "List of people from Warsaw")  
Further information: [Category:People from Warsaw](/wiki/Category:People_from_Warsaw "Category:People from Warsaw")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Marie_Curie_c1920.jpg/116px-Marie_Curie_c1920.jpg)](/wiki/File:Marie_Curie_c1920.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Benoit_Mandelbrot%2C_TED_2010_%283x4_cropped%29.jpg/118px-Benoit_Mandelbrot%2C_TED_2010_%283x4_cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Benoit_Mandelbrot,_TED_2010_(3x4_cropped).jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Samuel_Goldwyn_-_Jul_1919_EH.jpg/111px-Samuel_Goldwyn_-_Jul_1919_EH.jpg)](/wiki/File:Samuel_Goldwyn_-_Jul_1919_EH.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Robert_Lewandowski_FCB.jpg/123px-Robert_Lewandowski_FCB.jpg)](/wiki/File:Robert_Lewandowski_FCB.jpg)  
Famous people born in Warsaw, **clockwise from upper left** : [Maria Skłodowska-Curie](/wiki/Maria_Sk%C5%82odowska-Curie "Maria Skłodowska-Curie"), [Benoit Mandelbrot](/wiki/Benoit_Mandelbrot "Benoit Mandelbrot"), [Robert Lewandowski](/wiki/Robert_Lewandowski "Robert Lewandowski") and [Samuel Goldwyn](/wiki/Samuel_Goldwyn "Samuel Goldwyn")

One of the most famous people born in Warsaw was [Maria Skłodowska-Curie](/wiki/Marie_Curie "Marie Curie"), who achieved international recognition for her research on radioactivity and was the first female recipient of the Nobel Prize.^[\[267\]](#cite_note-nobelprize-269)^ Famous musicians include [Władysław Szpilman](/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_Szpilman "Władysław Szpilman"), [Frédéric Chopin](/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Chopin "Frédéric Chopin") and [Witold Lutosławski](/wiki/Witold_Lutos%C5%82awski "Witold Lutosławski"). Though Chopin was born in the village of [Żelazowa Wola](/wiki/%C5%BBelazowa_Wola "Żelazowa Wola"), about 60 km (37 mi) from Warsaw, he moved to the city with his family when he was seven months old.^[\[268\]](#cite_note-Lawrynowicz-270)^ [Casimir Pulaski](/wiki/Casimir_Pulaski "Casimir Pulaski"), a Polish general and hero of the [American Revolutionary War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War"), was born here in 1745.^[\[269\]](#cite_note-271)^ Other important people, who lived in Warsaw (although were not born here) are also [Rosa Luxemburg](/wiki/Rosa_Luxemburg "Rosa Luxemburg") and [L. L. Zamenhof](/wiki/L._L._Zamenhof "L. L. Zamenhof").{#cite_ref-271}

[Tamara de Lempicka](/wiki/Tamara_de_Lempicka "Tamara de Lempicka") was a famous artist born in Warsaw.^[\[270\]](#cite_note-lempicka-272)^ She was born Maria Górska in Warsaw to wealthy parents and in 1916 married a Polish lawyer Tadeusz Łempicki.^[\[271\]](#cite_note-marchand-273)^ Better than anyone else she represented the [art deco](/wiki/Art_deco "Art deco") style in painting and art.^[\[270\]](#cite_note-lempicka-272)^ Another notable artist born in the city was [Wojciech Fangor](/wiki/Wojciech_Fangor "Wojciech Fangor"). He was associated with [Op art](/wiki/Op_art "Op art") and [Color field](/wiki/Color_field "Color field") movements and recognized as a key figure in the history of Polish postwar [abstract art](/wiki/Abstract_art "Abstract art").^[\[272\]](#cite_note-NYT-274)^ [Nathan Alterman](/wiki/Nathan_Alterman "Nathan Alterman"), the Israeli poet, was born in Warsaw, as was [Moshe Vilenski](/wiki/Moshe_Vilenski "Moshe Vilenski"), the Israeli composer, lyricist, and pianist, who studied music at the [Warsaw Conservatory](/wiki/Warsaw_Conservatory "Warsaw Conservatory").^[\[273\]](#cite_note-jewishvirtuallibrary1-275)^{#cite_ref-jewishvirtuallibrary1_275-0}

[Russian Jewish](/wiki/Russia "Russia") poet and essayist [Osip Mandelstam](/wiki/Osip_Mandelstam "Osip Mandelstam"), one of the foremost members of the [Acmeist](/wiki/Acmeist_poetry "Acmeist poetry") school of poetry was born in Warsaw while it was part of the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire"). Other notables include [Samuel Goldwyn](/wiki/Samuel_Goldwyn "Samuel Goldwyn"), the founder of [Goldwyn Pictures](/wiki/Goldwyn_Pictures "Goldwyn Pictures"), mathematician [Benoit Mandelbrot](/wiki/Benoit_Mandelbrot "Benoit Mandelbrot"), physicist [Joseph Rotblat](/wiki/Joseph_Rotblat "Joseph Rotblat"), biochemist [Casimir Funk](/wiki/Casimir_Funk "Casimir Funk"), and [Moshe Prywes](/wiki/Moshe_Prywes "Moshe Prywes"), an Israeli physician who was the first President of [Ben-Gurion University of the Negev](/wiki/Ben-Gurion_University_of_the_Negev "Ben-Gurion University of the Negev"). Warsaw was the beloved city of [Isaac Bashevis Singer](/wiki/Isaac_Bashevis_Singer "Isaac Bashevis Singer"), which he described in many of his novels:^[\[274\]](#cite_note-jewish-theatre-276)^ "Warsaw has just now been destroyed. No one will ever see the Warsaw I knew. Let me just write about it. Let this Warsaw not disappear forever", he wrote.^[\[275\]](#cite_note-Burgin-277)^ Notable sportspeople born in Warsaw include footballers [Robert Lewandowski](/wiki/Robert_Lewandowski "Robert Lewandowski")^[\[276\]](#cite_note-278)^ and [Wojciech Szczęsny](/wiki/Wojciech_Szcz%C4%99sny "Wojciech Szczęsny")^[\[277\]](#cite_note-279)^ as well as tennis player [Iga Świątek](/wiki/Iga_%C5%9Awi%C4%85tek "Iga Świątek").^[\[278\]](#cite_note-280)^{#cite_ref-280}

### Twin towns and sister cities {#Twin_towns_and_sister_cities}
